Kept going on and on about how disrespectful we were and how we embarrassed her in front of the neighbours because someone might see us going to the hotel together. She literally made me promise not to do that again. Like I was eight years old, asking for permission to have a sleepover. I felt so stupid agreeing to it, but I didn't want the drama. So when Christmas planning came around, Jake's parents invited us to visit them in Mexico. They retired there a few years ago, and they're super chill people. We decided to go because, honestly, it sounded amazing. Beach weather in December while everyone back home is freezing their asses off? Yes, please. But here's where I got a little sneaky. We didn't tell my parents we weren't coming home for

Sister in law snooped and stole our baby's name, then announced it right after she gave birth. But her face immediately dropped when she realised that we tricked her. My sister in law, Maya, has always been competitive with me since the day I married her brother Jake. She couldn't handle that someone else was getting attention and what she considered her family. When Jake and I got engaged, I tried to announce her own engagement at our party. When we bought our first house, she suddenly started house hunting, too. So when we both ended up pregnant at the same time, I knew the competition was about to get intense. Maya was due just two weeks before me. And from the moment we announced, she became absolutely obsessed with finding out our baby name choice. At first it started innocently enough. She'd casually ask during family dinners, have you guys thought about names yet? When we'd de flesh, she'd push harder. Come on, just give me a hint. But then it escalated. Maya started showing up at our house unannounced, trying to peek at any baby books we had lying around. She'd walk through our nursery and comment on everything, clearly fishing for clues. She even asked my mother in law to pressure us into sharing our choice. The breaking point came when I caught her literally going through our mail when she thought we weren't looking. She was flipping through baby magazines and packages desperately searching for any Evidence of our name decision, my husband thought I was being paranoid when I told him I suspected Maya wanted to steal our name and use it first. She wouldn't do that, he said, but I knew better. This is exactly the kind of petty move Maya would pull. That's when I decided to set a trap. I created bacon twist boards filled with names I'd never actually consider using. I strategically left a notebook open on our kitchen counter with Final Decision written in big letters next to the name Aurora Rose. When Maya came over for dinner, I even coordinated with my mom to call me while Maya was within earshot, having a completely fake conversation about how Aurora fits so perfectly with your family naming tradition and I'm so excited you finally decided. Maya took the bait completely. Over the next few weeks, she started casually bringing up the name Aurora in random conversations, testing how we'd react. Aurora is such a beautiful name, don't you think, she'd say. Watching our faces carefully, I played along perfectly, acting slightly uncomfortable whenever she mentioned it, like she'd stumbled onto our secret. Two weeks later, Maya went into labor. Within an hour of giving birth, she posted on Facebook, welcome to the world, Baby Aurora Rose. Our little princess has finally arrived. The whole family flooded the comments with congratulations, but I noticed Maya kept checking to see if I'd responded. She was clearly waiting for my reaction to Her surprise, the next day at the hospital, Maya was practically glowing with smugness when I walked into her room. She actually had the audacity to say, I hope you don't mind that we ended up using Aurora when she was born. It just felt so right for our daughter. I know you guys were considering it, too. That's when I pulled out my phone and showed her our real pic.

My birthday, my boss's son called me into his office and said, here's my surprise for you. You're fired. I left quietly without making a scene, then told my husband to just smiled. Four hours later, panic broke out, 98 missed calls. I've been the head chef at Romano's for three years. When I started, it was a struggling family restaurant with two star reviews and empty tables. I transformed everything, rebuilt the menu, trained the staff, forced local ingredients. Within a year, we were booked solid with a waiting list. But when old Mister Romano died last spring, everything changed. His son Giovanni inherited the place and he had different ideas. Cut costs, use frozen ingredients, fire half the kitchen staff. People can't tell the difference anyway, he'd say, counting receipts. While I fought to maintain the standards that built our reputation, I refused to compromise our lamb. Also buco was legendary. Our house made pasta brought people from three states over. I wasn't about to ruin that for Giovanni's profit margins. So on my 32nd birthday, after our biggest week ever, he called me into the cramped office above the dining room. Birthday balloons from the staff still hung in the kitchen below. Here's my surprise for you, he said with this smug grin. You're fired effective immediately. You're too difficult to work with. I stood there, soft stained apron still tied around my waist, watching him lean back in his father's old chair like he just solved World hunger. I didn't argue, didn't cry, just untied my apron, set it on his desk and walked out past the confused prep cooks who'd worked under me for years. The drive home felt endless. Three years of my life gone. My reputation, my team, my recipes all handed over to someone who thought ketchup was a vegetable. My husband, Scott was waiting in our kitchen with a bottle of wine and that knowing smile he gets when he's up to something. How did the birth a shift go, he asked. Already pouring two glasses. Terrible. Giovanni fired me. His grin widened. Perfect timing. What do you mean perfect timing? I just lost my job. We have a mortgage, Scott bills. He pulled out his laptop, fingers dancing across the key board. Remember that food critic from the times who came in last month, Julia Chen, the one who wrote that amazing review about your lamb dish? Yeah, of course. She said it was transcendent. Why? Well, Scott said, turning the screen toward me, she's been discreetly asking around town about hiring a private chef for her daughter's wedding next weekend. Very exclusive, very high paying. I may have already told her you'd be available. I stared at the email thread. Julia had been trying to reach me for weeks, but Giovanni never passed along messages. She was offering $15,000 for a single event, more than I made in three months at Romano's. Scott, how did you, my phone buzz Text message, then another. Then it started ringing. Giovanni's number flashed on the screen. I let it go to voicemail. Then more calls. The assistant manager, the sous chef, even the dishwasher. By the time I checked, there were 47 missed calls. And count, Scott was refreshing his laptop cackling. Oh, this is beautiful. Look, a skating review had just gone live on every major food blog and review site, posted an hour ago, right around when Giovanni would have been running dinner service without me. Romano's Restaurant, a spectacular fall from Grace, read the headline. The review was brutal. Food quality has completely collapsed, undercooked chicken, rude service. Avoid at all costs.

Family tradition ruined your family. In my family, skinny daughters were worthless, and fat daughters were currency. The heavier you were, the higher your bride price. Every girl at 13 got sent to the fattening house for a minimum of two years. Where gaining weight wasn't a suggestion, it was survival. I grew up watching my older cousins disappear into that house walking on their own two feet and wheeled out in chairs too heavy to stand. My cousin Amara went in at 115 pounds and came out at 340. She was married within a week to a man who paid extra for her stretch marks. They called them beauty lines. But I saw how she gasped for air walking to her own wedding. The process was simple. Six meals a day, each one monitored by the house mothers. You sat in a circle while they ladled bowls of crushed millet mixed with butter, sugar and milk down your throat. If you threw up, they'd make you eat the vomit. Waste nothing, gain everything, my aunt would say cheerfully, while girls cried into their bowls. 4,000 calories per meal, minimum. They had tricks to make you hungrier. Salt baths that made you retain water, medications that increased appetite. Exercise was forbidden, except for throat stretches to help you swallow faster. My sister Kayla tried doing squats in secret. They caught her and force fed her until her stomach. Nearly as punishment, she had to eat standing up for a month. I was 11 when I found the death book hidden in my grandmother's closet while looking for Eid money. Names and weights filled three notebooks. Amara, age 22, heart failure, 389 pounds. Fatu, age 19, diabetes coma, 412 pounds. Mariama, age 24, stroke, 445 pounds. Page after page of girls who never made it to third. The weights next to their names weren't just numbers. They were their sale prices. But what really made me sick was the profit column. Beside each death, my grandmother had calculated how much money the family made from their bride price minus funeral costs. Tattoo's death netted the family $85,000. Her husband kept the dowry even though she only lived four months after the wedding. That's when I started planning. I was smart about it. Told everyone I was starting a traditional cooking circle for younger girls to prepare them for the fattening house. We met every Thursday in my uncle's garage teaching recipes. But what I really taught was chemistry. The exact amount of salt to retain 20 pounds of water weight for weigh ins. How to make fake fat suits from layered fabric and memory foam. Ways to trigger temporary bloating that would disappear after measurements. We got creative as hell. Practice eating competitions where girls Learned to hide food in their cheeks and spit it out. Later developed a system of herbal teas that lost appetite while making your face look puffy. Made our own weight gain shakes that were actually Just protein powder and laxatives. The house mothers thought we were so dedicated. My genius move was suggesting we document our journey for marriage advertisements. We took photos, but Learned exactly which angles and clothing made you look 50 pounds heavier. Bought a broken scale that added 80 pounds and swapped it during official weigh ins. By the time I turned 13 and entered the house myself, I had a network of 15 girls, all trained in the art of fake fattening. We shared clothes that had hidden weights sewn into the hems. Learned to walk slow and breathe heavy like we were carrying extra weight. Perfected the arm positions that made our pictures look massive. The house mothers praised us constantly. Look how well Alia gains, they'd say, as I stepped on the rigged scale. We became their star students while secretly flushing thousands of calories down the toilet every night. Some girls Learned to throw up silently. Others developed jaw techniques that made swallowing look real.

The most disturbing school announcement your school has ever made. I was in the middle of texting my friends the road work ahead Vine during math class when the principal coughed over the school intercom, the telltale sign that he was about to make an announcement. Attention all students and staff. No one is to leave their classrooms. Everyone must remain seated until further notice. This is for your safety as much as ours. Usually no one gave an F what the teacher said, but now it was so quiet that you could hear a pin drop. Even missus Peterson stopped writing on the board mid sentence. We heard ambulances outside and she told us to sit in our seats. We were all glancing at each other around the room, wide eyed and curious. Nobody said anything, but we were all thinking the same thing. One of the teachers had died. The red and blue lights flashed across the walls, and we heard screams from the other grades echoing throughout the building. Missus Peterson told us that it wasn't a big deal and we should all be focusing on our studies. But she could barely get the words out from how hard she was hyperventilating, so much so that she didn't even care. As we all started to take our phones out and text our theories into the Snapchat group chat about what was going down, then we heard it. Footsteps running past our door. Heavy ones. Multiple sets I Couldn't help myself. I had to look. I crept to the door and peeked through the window. Two paramedics were sprinting down the hall pushing a wheeled stretcher, the kind you see on medical shows when someone's heart stops. Get away from the door, Eve. Missus Peterson whispered, voice shaking. She was scared, too. I sat down and immediately texted everyone what I had seen. Suddenly, people's bitmojis were popping up faster than a whack a mole game. Maybe someone finally took out Mr. Jordan, the creepy history teacher? Nah, someone definitely just had an allergic reaction. That allergies go crazy. Another one said that maybe someone had taken too much vent. Missus Peterson tried to continue the lesson. Something about the Revolutionary War, but nobody was listening. How could we care about some battle from 200 years ago when someone might be dying down the hall right now? Finally, there was a knock at the door. It was the principal standing beside a police officer. Eve O'Brien, the principal announced. My heart dropped. That was me. Can you come with us, please? Bring your things. I silently got up and followed, not knowing what the f was going on. In the hallway, I could see the paramedics near the gym. One was sitting on the floor filling out paperwork. The stretcher was off to the side. When they brought me into the office, I was faced with my parents sitting on the wooden chairs. Well, my parents are divorced. And I hadn't seen them sit in the same room since I was seven. So now I was really confused. Suddenly, my mom stood up and lunged at me for a hug. I'm so sorry, she repeated over and over. I pushed her off of me. Guys, it's okay. I mean, the

What made you say, yep, I'm going to die? I was driving home from my girlfriend's place around midnight when my car started making this horrible grinding noise. Steam was pouring from under the hood. I pulled over on this empty back road and called Del AAA, but they said it would be two hours minimum. That's when this pickup truck pulled up behind me. Guy gets out and walks over, probably mid 40s, wearing coveralls, like a mechanic. Seemed friendly enough. Car trouble, he asked. Yeah, I think it's the radiator. I said I can take a look if you want. I run a shop in town. He popped my hood and poked around for a minute. Yep, radiator hose is shot, but I got some tools in my truck that might get you home. While he was getting his tools, I noticed something weird. His truck had no license plate, just an empty bracket where it should be. He came back with a toolbox and started working. That's when I saw the inside of his truck through the open door. There were zip ties scattered on the passenger seat, lots of them, and what looked like a roll of duct tape. You know, he said, not looking up from the engine, you picked a real isolated spot to break down. Nobody comes down this road at night. My stomach dropped. Yeah, just bad luck, I guess, or good luck, depending on how you look at it. He glanced Up at me with this weird smile for me. Anyway, I started backing away slowly. Actually, I think I'll just wait for the tow truck. Tow truck. He laughed. I called and canceled that while you weren't looking. Told them you got it sorted out. He pulled something from his toolbox, not a wrench, but a Taser. Now we can do this easy or hard. Your choice. I turned and ran into the woods behind me. I heard him yell, you're just making this more fun. I crashed through branches in total darkness using my phone's flashlight. I could hear him following, breaking through the brush behind me. The light from his flashlight kept getting closer. I tripped over a fallen log and went down hard, scraping my hands and knees. When I looked back, his light was maybe 30 yards away. That's when I saw it.

How did the system fail your child? My daughter's school counselor called during my lunch break. We need you to come immediately, her voice trembled. Lily's refusing to speak to anyone. My heart stopped. Lily, my bubbly 7 year old who never stopped talking, refusing to speak. The same girl who gave a presentation on butterflies to angels at the park last weekend. I dropped everything and broke every speed limit driving to her school. The halls were eerily quiet. My heels echoing against the colorful tile floors lined with student artwork. Lily's butterfly drawing stared back at me from the star student wall. I found my daughter curled into herself in the corner chair, knees pulled tight against her chest. Her eyes were vacant, unfocused. Her yellow dress, her favorite, was wrinkled and dirty at the hem. The sparky butterfly clip I'd fastened in her hair that morning was gone. Lily Bean, I whispered, kneeling beside her. When I touched her shoulder, she flinched like my fingers were made of fire. I'd never seen her like this, not when she fell off her bike and needed stitches, not when our dog died. What happened? I demanded, turning to the counselor, fighting to keep panic from overtaking me. She shifted uncomfortably. We're not sure. She was fine at recess. Then her teacher sent her to music class. When Mister Roberts brought her back, she was like this. The principal joined us. His tie is slightly askew. Children sometimes have emotional Episodes, he said, not meeting my eyes. Perhaps something upset her with her friends. I took Lily home that night. She wouldn't eat dinner, wouldn't talk, just clutched her favorite stuffed rabbit with the missing ear. While helping her change into pajamas, I noticed dark purple bruises encircling her wrists like macabre bracelets. My stomach lurched. Baby, who did this to you? I asked, trying to keep my voice steady. Her tiny voice finally broke through. So quiet I had to lean close. Mr Roberts said, it's our secret game. If I tell, something bad will happen to you and daddy. My blood turned to ice. Mr Roberts, the beloved music teacher who'd been with the school for five years, the one parents fought to have their children placed with because he made special time for talented students. I called the police that night with a child psychologist help. The interview revealed everything. For months, Roberts had been taking special students to the supply closet.

During is realizing girls won't watch a dog die in a movie, but we'll watch how a serial killer murdered 20+ people. Like, she'll cover her eyes during Marley and me, but sit criss cross on the couch eating Hot Cheetos while Jeffrey Dahmer explains how he kept human remains in his fridge. You know, she'll be like, oh my god, turn it off, the dog's about to die. But five minutes later, she'll be like, so anyway, he kept the heads in the closet and the neighbors heard noises. They'll cry if a golden retriever gets a haircut, but somehow have zero problems listening to real 9 1 1 calls from 2,003 at 2:00am with captions while excitedly smiling. And if you ask them why, they'll hit you with, nah, because it's psychological. It's like how the brain works. No, no, no, he ate people. This is not therapy. And the scariest part, they'll finish the entire series, shut the TV off, look you dead in the eyes and go, anyway, I think I want a lavender oat milk latte. I'm sorry, I'm not ready for that. You were just watching a man dismember humans while folding laundry, but somehow you can't handle a fictional dog death.

What feels like an orgasm, but isn't an orgasm. 1. Waking up thinking you gotta go to work but then realize you have the day off and then going back to sleep. 2. When you finally lay down after a long day and all the muscles in your back relax at once. 3. The water in my ear finally coming out nice and warm. Four. Finally peeing when you really, really, really, really, really, really, really need to go. 5. When you're sick with a bad head cold and your nose is completely blocked on both sides and there's so much inflammation it feels hot within. Then when the combination of meds and anatomical adjustments hit that sweet spot and one nostril spontaneously unblocks as you feel the pressure gradient change and cool air rushes in for the first time in hours. 6. Drinking water when you're thirsty as fuck. 7. Farting out your stomachache. 8. Popping your back just right so that it feels like your soul leaves your body. 9. Running a poison Ivy rash under nearly scalding hot water. It's painful and orgasmic at once and it stops the itching for a while. 10. Scratching an itch. Eleven. Cold side of the pillow. 12. Pooping in your own toilet after a long vacation. 13. Scratching a mosquito bite that's on your ankle for some reason. 14. Getting in the bed with your socks on in the winter, warming up a bit and then taking off your socks. 15. Drinking water after a night out. 16. Sneezing. 17. Closing your eyes after a tiring day.

You're given a choice never having to shower or never having to poop. You're presented with two options never having to shower again or never having to poop again. Here's how they work never shower again. With this power, you're always clean, fresh, and hygienic without ever needing to step into a shower or bath. Your skin remains free of dirt and oils, and you naturally smell great no matter what. However, you'll still need to handle things like styling your hair, shaving, or other grooming habits that aren't directly tied to cleanliness. While you'll never have to worry about bad hygiene, you'll still need to manage the aesthetic aspects of your appearance. Never poop again. If you choose this option, you'll never need to defecate again. Your digestive system functions perfectly, but waste is magically removed before it reaches your bowels. You won't feel bowel pressure, discomfort, or any health issues related to digestion. However, you'll still have to urinate on a normal schedule, and your body otherwise operates as it does now, minus the inconvenience of bathroom trips. For No. 2, both powers come without any hidden drawbacks or consequences. You simply gain the benefit of removing one of life's recurring annoyances. So would you embrace the freedom of never showering while staying perfectly fresh, or would you choose the relief of never needing to poop again? Which power would improve your life the most?

What's the most boyish thing he did that made your heart explode? 1, he wore mismatched socks on our first date. Not because it was a quirky fashion choice, but because he genuinely didn't notice. I pointed it out and he got so flustered, mumbling something about laundry. Then he looked at me totally serious and said, are you gonna cancel the date now? Like a nervous middle schooler, I fell for him right there, socks and all. Two, we were at the arcade and he got way too invested in the claw machine, not for himself, but because he saw a stuffed turtle. He said, look like me when I'm cranky. It took him six tries, 20 bucks and some serious trash talk to the machine, but he got it when he handed it to me, he said, now you can hold me when I'm not around. That turtle's still on my bed. 3, he doesn't know how to cook at all. But one night I was sick and he showed up with instant noodles, gummy bears and a handwritten get well card drawn in blue pen. He spelled fever wrong, but he also drew me as a superhero, complete with a cape and a little speech bubble that said, I got this. I swear I got better instantly. He made me a playlist titled Songs That Remind Me of You and forgot to check the shuffle setting. First song was Shrek 2 soundtrack. I asked if it was A joke. He panicked and said, no, it's romantic. He really loved her. 5. He tied my shoelace because it came undone and said, safety first, princess, like he was a knight or something. I giggled and he turned red. 6. I caught him flexing in the mirror when he thought I wasn't looking. He whispered, she likes strong arms to himself. I had to pretend I didn't hear so he wouldn't die of embarrassment. 7. We walked past a Lego store and he stopped mid sentence, gasped and said, can we please go in just for a minute? Thirty minutes later, he was building a tiny pirate ship and explaining the lore of each mini figure. Eight, he named a raccoon that lives near his apartment. Captain bites and leaves snacks for it every time it shows up. He waves like it's a neighbor. First time I saw it, he said, look, he came to meet you. 9. He once got mad at a seagull because it looked at me wrong. Said, what's it got to squawk about, huh? And puffed his chest like he was ready to square up. 10, he lost a round of UNO and threw a mini tantrum, arms crossed, pouty lip, the whole thing. Then he looked up at me totally serious and said, you're lucky I love you or this would be war.

Her husband's female friend finally crossed the line. My husband's friend Kate always had to be the main character in every situation. When someone else had good news, Kate suddenly had better news. At group dinners, she'd hijack any conversation within five minutes. I couldn't stand her, but I put up with it because she and Zach had been friends since college. After my husband and I announced our pregnancy at 12 weeks, things with Kate got really weird. Suddenly, Kate was everywhere we went sporting a small baby bump. She showed up at our favorite brunch spot rubbing her belly. She enrolled in our exact prenatal yoga class. She even switched to our OB practice. Nobody questioned it because these things happen and women get pregnant. At the same time, she posted weekly bump photos on Instagram and everyone congratulated her just like they did me. Three months in, one of our friends mentioned something strange at a girls night. She said Kate's belly looked bigger the previous Tuesday at Book Club than it did at Saturday's barbecue. When she brought it up, Kate burst into tears about how cruel it was to comment on a pregnant woman's body. She went on about water retention and bloating and how pregnant women deal with enough judgment without their friends piling on. Our friend felt terrible and apologized profuse while the rest of us comforted Kate. After that night, nobody dared mention anything about her appearance again, even though I started Noticing her bump size seemed to fluctuate, too. That's when things got uncomfortable. Kate started making comments about how wild it was that we got pregnant around the same time. She'd joke about our babies being best friends, maybe even more than friends someday. Then the jokes got stranger, like when she said pregnancy brain made her forget exactly when she conceived. And wasn't it funny how close our due dates were? She started showing up at every single appointment Zach and I had, always in the waiting room when we arrived. Claiming her appointment was right before or after hours during our maternity photo shoot at the park, she appeared with her own photographer, saying what a coincidence that she booked the same spot. The photographer later told me Kate had called asking what time we'd be there. Everything exploded at my baby shower. My sister threw this beautiful garden party with all our family and friends there to celebrate. Halfway through opening gifts, Kate stood up and clinked her glass to make an announcement. With tears streaming down her face, she placed her hand on her belly and said, I have the most wonderful news to share with everyone. Zack and I are having a baby together. The entire party gasped and she continued with a huge smile. I know this is unconventional, but isn't it beautiful that our babies will be siblings?

What's the worst I hate to break it to you, moment you had with someone? My dad showed up at my apartment with flowers for me like I was his girlfriend. And my fiance had to tell him he was my father, not my husband. I always knew my dad was weird about me. When my parents divorced when I was nine, my mom moved on pretty quick. Found herself a nice guy named Paul who treated me like a normal stepdaughter. But my dad, he never dated anyone. Ever. He'd always say I was his whole world and he didn't need anyone else. First it felt special. He'd pick me up from school with my favourite candy. He'd take me shopping and let me get whatever I wanted. He called our Saturday hangouts daddy daughter dates, which seemed normal enough when I was 10, but things got weird as I got older. When I started wearing makeup in eighth grade, he threw it all away and said I was too beautiful to need that garbage. When I got my first phone, he demanded all my passwords because he needed to protect me from predators. He'd scroll through my texts every night at dinner. High school was worse. He hated all my friends, especially the guys. If I hung out with anyone he didn't approve of, he'd give me the silent treatment for days. Just sit at dinner staring at his plate, acting like I didn't exist until I apologized. The worst was when I told him I was dating Trevor when I was 17. We were driving to target, and I casually mentioned I had a boyfriend. He pulled into the parking lot and just started crying. Like, ugly sobbing. He said I was throwing away everything we had together for some stupid boy who didn't really know me. I felt so guilty. I broke up with Trevor the next week. College gave me some space. He'd call me three times a day. If I didn't answer, he'd drive the two hours to campus to make sure I was okay. My roommate thought it was sweet at first, until she saw him show up at 1:00am because I'd fallen asleep without texting him goodnight. After graduation, I moved to my own apartment and met Malik at my job. He was calm.

Girlfriend said she wanted an open relationship, but got mad when I actually opened it. So my girlfriend Gabrielle drops this bombshell on me last month over Chinese takeout. I want us to see other people. I nearly choked on my lo Mein. We've been together two years. Just signed a lease together three months ago. Wait, what? Why? She gets this look like she's been rehearsing this. I met someone at my yoga class. My name is Jeremy, and there's just this connection. So you want to break up? No. I love our stability. I just want to explore my options while keeping you as my foundation. Foundation? Like I'm concrete? She's building on Gabriel, that's not how relationships work. It could be. No pressure, no jealousy. We both get to experience new things. I set down my food. Okay, but if we're doing this, it go was both ways. I'm dating, too. She actually laughed, threw her head back and cackled. Oh, honey, good luck with that. See, Gabrielle's always thought she was out of my league. I'm a software developer, pretty quiet. She's this Instagram yoga instructor with 12,000 followers. She constantly makes jokes about how she settled down early and how I outkicked my coverage. I'm serious, Gabrielle. If you're seeing other people, so am I. Sure, baby. You do that. The condescension lit something inside me. That weekend, while she was at Jeremy's overnight, I downloaded every dating app, updated my profile, mentioned I code And play guitar. Matches started rolling in immediately. Turns out stable guys with jobs are popular. First date was Whitney, a teacher. We talked for three hours. She actually listened when I explained my work. Day two was Tiffany, a nurse who played guitar. We jammed together. She said I had really good hands. Gabriel barely noticed I was gone. Then my third match was Jeremy, Gabriel's yoga instructor. Jeremy, his profile said. Looking for genuine connection. I thought, why not see what this guy's about? We matched instantly met for coffee downtown. I could see why Gabrielle was interested. Tall, athletic, at Zen Vibe. But as we talked, something clicked. He was smart, funny, asked about my projects with actual curiosity. Can I be honest? He said after an hour. There's this woman in my class who's been very forward. Keeps talking about how her boyfriend doesn't understand her. My stomach dropped. What's her name? Gabrielle. She says he's boring, that she's settling until something better comes along. He sipped his coffee. I'm not interested in being someone's upgrade. I wanna be someone's first choice. I stared at him. Jeremy, I need to tell you something. I'm Gabrielle's boyfriend. His eyes went wide. Oh, god. I'm so sorry. She made it sound like you guys were roommates. We ended up talking for two more hours. Tons in common. SCI fi, movies, video games, similar music taste. This might sound crazy, Jeremy said, but wanna hang out again as friends? Friends turned into something more pretty quickly. Next week, Jeremy suggested

Not boyfriend, said we weren't a couple. So I introduced him to my actual boyfriend. For 8 months, sane, acted like my boyfriend in every way possible. We hung out four times a week. He'd sleep over constantly, even had his own drawer at my place. He'd get visibly jealous whenever other guys talk to me at parties, always finding excuse, this is to interrupt conversations or pull me away. He bought me flowers just because, remembered my coffee order perfectly. And we'd spend entire weekends together binge watching shows and cooking dinner like a real couple. My friends all assumed we were dating. My family invited him to barbecue. Even his mom would ask about his girlfriend when she called. But whenever anyone directly asked if we were together, Zane would laugh it off awkwardly. Oh, no, we're just really close friends. I'm not ready for anything serious right now. It stung every single time, but I kept hoping he'd come around. I thought maybe he just needed more time to feel comfortable with labels. Last Friday night changed everything. We were at Kelsey's birthday party and this girl, Alexis from his work showed up. She was clear flirting with him all night, touching his arm, laughing way too loud at his jokes. Finally, she looked me up and down and asked directly, so are you his girlfriend or what? Without hesitation, Zane immediately said, oh, no, we're definitely not together. I'm completely single. Actually, he even stepped lightly. Away from me. When he said it, the humiliation hit me like a truck. Everyone with an earshot was staring. Kelsey looked mortified. For me, I felt my cheeks burning with embarrassment. But instead of running away, crying like I want.

For it. Before anyone could react, my niece walked straight up to the CEO, looked him up and down and asked in her clear carrying voice, are you the big boss man? The partners froze. The CEO raised his eyebrows and nodded slowly. My career flashed before my eyes. My niece unzipped her backpack and pulled out a slightly squished chocolate cupcake and plastic wrap. My aunt said the big boss man here is super scary and might make her mess up her words because her brain gets wobbly when she's nervous. She placed the cupcake in front of the stunned CEO. When I get scared at school, my mom says sugar helps brave come out. So I saved this from my lunch for you so you can stop being scary and my aunt's brain can work again. The silence was deafening. I contemplated whether I could fit under the conference table. Then the CE E O, this man who reportedly made junior associates cry during performance reviews let out a deep genuine laugh. Well, he said, unwrapping the cupcake, that's the most on best assessment of my interview technique I've ever received. He took a bite then turned to me with frosting on his lip. Your niece is right. I've been unnecessarily intimidating. Let's restart this conversation, but this time I'd like to hear about how you handled the West Moreland case. I read your brief. It was impressive. As the interview continued with a completely different tone, my Niece sat on the CEO's leather chair, spinning happily, occasionally offering every 1 life advice. When we finally left, the CEO walked us to the elevator. We'll be in touch very soon, he said, and bent down to my niece's level. And thank you for the cupcake. It definitely helped my brave come out. I got the job offer the next morning. Two years later, the cupcake story is still legendary at the firm.

While chilling in my room, my sister busted down my door and asked, did you eat my candy? Yeah, I'm sorry. You had a bunch in that pack. I thought it wouldn't be bad if I ate a couple. Cecilia rushed over and grabbed my face, forcing my mouth open. She stared inside like she was looking for something specific, and her face went white. We have to make you throw up right now. Why? I thought it was just candy. My voice came out muffled because she was still holding my jaw. She dragged me to the bathroom and started shoving her fingers toward my throat. I pulled away, disgusted and confused, but she kept trying. When that didn't work, she ran to the kitchen and came back with a glass of lemon juice mixed with baking soda. The smell alone made me gag, but she forced me to drink it. Nothing happened except my stomach felt weird and bubbly. Cecilia then tried making me spin in circles. She said motion sickness might help. I spun until I was dizzy, but still nothing. She made me drink salt water next, which tasted horrible and made me cough, but I still didn't throw up. She was getting more desperate by the second. Celia, what's wrong? Just tell me what I ate. I was scared now because she was acting insane. She ignored me and ran to get ipecac syrup from the medicine cabinet, but the bottle was expired and empty. She started crying, actual tears, and pulling at her hair. I'd never seen my sister this freaked out about anything. She grabbed my shoulders and shook me, asking exactly where I found the candy and how many I ate. I told her it was in the small round container in her backpack, the one that looked like an Altoid's tin, but fancier. She asked what color the pills were and if I was sure I ate them all. I said they were different colors, like some were white and some were pink, and maybe one was green. I eating at least six or seven while gaming because they tasted kind of sweet. My mom heard all the chaos and came upstairs to find Cecilia kneeling next to me by the toilet. What's going on here? Cecilia whispered something in Mom's ear, and I watched my mother's expression change from annoyed to terrified in about two seconds. She grabbed her car keys and told me to put on shoes immediately because we were going to the hospital. No explanation, just pure panic on both their faces. The car ride was the scariest 15 minutes of my life.

Sister in law. She has no right to know everything about my marriage just because she raised my husband. My husband, Jake, lost his parents when he was 8 and his older sister, Becca, basically became his mom. She was only 16 at the time, but somehow managed to keep them both afloat. Jake always talked about how she gave up her teenage years to make sure he had clean clothes and hot meals. I get that their bond is special. I really do. But Becca acts like she owns Jake. When we first started dating three years ago, she'd call him every single night at exactly nine PM if he didn't pick up, she'd blow up his phone until he did. She needed to know where he was, who he was with, what he ate for dinner. It was weird, but Jake said it was normal for them. Then we moved in together last year. Becca had a spare key to our apartment. Within a week, he'd show up unannounced on Saturday mornings with groceries, reorganizing our fridge and telling me I was buying the wrong brand of cereal. For Jake, she knew his favorite everything better than I did and she made sure I knew it. The worst part was how she'd interrogate me about our relationship. She'd corner me in the kitchen while Jake was in the bathroom and ask stuff like, are you two using Protection and how often do you fight? When I told her, It wasn't her business. Get this hurt look and say I'm just looking out for my baby brother. Jake always defended her. He'd say I was being sensitive and that Becca just cared about us. But it got worse. After we got engaged 6 months ago, Becca demanded to see our bank statements because she needed to make sure Jake was making smart financial decisions. She wanted to approve our wedding venue, our guest list, even my dress. When I said no to helping pick my wedding dress, she cried to Jake about how I was shutting her out of important moments. Last month was the breaking point. Jake and I had our first real fight about money. Nothing crazy, just normal couple stuff about whether to buy a new couch or save the money we.

Update. My girlfriend said I need space. Let's just be friends. I replied, sure. Then I removed her name from joint subscriptions, reclaimed her car keys and changed our Netflix password. 72 hours later, she was knocking desperately on my door. Part two, the last week has been a master class in escalating entitlement and delusion. I feel like I'm a character in a movie I never auditioned for. The 48 hour deadline came and went. Aura didn't call, didn't text, just silence. So as promised, I called a locksmith and had the locks on my apartment changed. It cost me $250, but the peace of mind was priceless. I also installed a small discreet security camera in my living room pointing at the front door. A little voice told me it would be a good investment. That little voice was right. The day after I changed the locks, the first dirty trick happened. I got a call from my credit card company's fraud department. Apparently someone had tried to report my car as stolen. They went through the automated system, but because some security questions were answered incorrectly, it was flagged for review. I confirmed the card was in my possession and they added extra security notes to my account. Trick No. 2 was far more serious and happened two days later. I got a calendar invite for a mandatory meeting from HR. The subject was just follow up conversation. My boss, Mark and a woman from HR named Susan were on the invite. My stomach twisted into a knot. I walked into the small conference room and they were both there looking serious. This wasn't going to be a casual chat. Susan started, her voice neutral and professional. Thanks for.
NA

My parents worship my sister, so I picked my brother instead. My brother Joe and I have always been close, but not because we're similar. It's because our parents made it so damn clear who they actually cared about. Joe has a twin sister, Jill, and our parents have always treated her like she's royalty. They wanted a daughter so bad they practically forgot Joe existed. Jill got the attention, the shopping trips, the praise. Joe got ignored. So I stepped in. I started doing little things for him, taking him out with my friends when Jill went on her mall princess adventures, cheering him on at school plays while our parents skipped out for one of Jill's glittery pageants. First it was just pity. But over time, I realised something. I actually like Joe. He's real funny, grounded. Meanwhile, Jill's grown into this bratty, entitled, can't be bothered drama machine. Now they're both graduating. Jill's heading to some fancy school in San Francisco, fully funded by Mommy and daddy, of course. Joe got into a school near me in Seattle. He earned a full ride scholarship. You'd think that'd make our parents proud, but no, they're using it as an excuse to not give him a single cent. You know, K, oh, you got a scholarship, cool. Figure the rest out on your own. So I called a few people while on Facetime with Joe, trying to help him line up a decent job for the fall, He's better off not being financially tied to our parents anyway, that with their money comes their control. He started to feel better, like he wasn't complete, completely screwed. And then the next day, Jill starts blowing up my phone. Apparently she overheard the whole thing, starts demanding I help her find a job, too, because she doesn't wanna hear dad nagging her about money. I told her politely that I don't know anyone in SF. She's better off just asking our parents. That's when she lost it, called me out for favoring Joe over her, said I was picking sides. And honestly, yeah, I am. I don't even deny it anymore. Joe deserves someone in his corner. Jill has everyone else. She doesn't need me.

Craziest small town story. A year after my wife died, my nine year old daughter Lily finally tried to play soccer again. Do you think mom can see me from heaven, she asked. I told her, absolutely. The team coach, Bradley Morrison came, highly recommended, two time regional championships, played D1 college, ran summer camps for elite players. During tryouts, he shook my hand firmly and said all the right things about building character through sport. But something felt off when he barely looked at Lily during introductions. And during the first and second practice, Lily never left the bench. Same with the second and third. By Game 2, when she sat there for 90 minutes straight while other girls rotated positions, I figured it was just some sort of misunderstanding. So as soon as practice ended, I approached Morrison. He immediately pulled me aside to where no one could listen. Mike, can I be straight with you, he asked. His tone was harsh. I nodded. I've been coaching for 15 years. Children from broken homes, single parents, divorce, death, it creates weak players. Playing time goes to kids from intact families. She lost her mother, I exclaimed. Rage boiled my blood. I literally couldn't process what I was hearing. Exactly my point, he said, while shrugging. I wanted to tear him a new one, but I couldn't because Lily was staring at me from the car wide eyed and hopeful. So I channeled my rage into something productive that Weekend I posted on the community Facebook page, free soccer skills clinic every Saturday morning. All kids are welcome, no experience needed. The response was immediate. Turns out Morrison had quite a few bench warmers. Kevin, whose parents just divorced. Maria, living with her aunt while her mom was in rehab. By the third Saturday, we had 28 kids showing up to Lincoln Park. I taught them everything I remembered from Sarah's old playbooks, basic drills, footwork, but mostly just let them play. By Week 4, our Saturday group had grown to almost 40 kids. What started as a simple skills clinic became something bigger. These kids were finding their confidence again. Words spread through the soccer community. Parents started asking why so many kids from Morrison's team were attending outside training. Some even pulled their kids from his team entirely.

Made your parents completely regret grounding you in 10th grade? I got home one night at 4:00am after sneaking out to a boy's house and thought I was in the clear. I climbed up onto my roof, slid my window open as quietly as I possibly could, and right as I stepped inside, my light turned on. I almost had a heart attack and screamed as I saw my dad sitting in my room waiting for me. I could immediately see he was pissed. Fun night, he said. He had my iPad open, showing all the text messages between me. Embarrassed, but also knew I was done for. Dad spent the entire next day installing motion sensors on every door and window. Sync to his phone so he'd get an alert anything opened after ten PM. Mom changed the hiding spot for my phone three times, finally settling on locking it in their bedroom safe. You've lost our trust completely, Maya. She kept saying. You're not doing doing this anymore. What if you get pregnant? I tried to explain we didn't do anything, but they told me I was on complete lockdown for a month. No phone, no friends, no leaving my room except for school and meals. I'm not that good at reading, so I literally spent the entire week staring at the ceiling wondering what Brody was doing. My best friend Chloe lived three houses down, and I could see her bedroom light flickering as she probably scrolled Through TikTok or Facetimed. Our other friends. Without my phone, I had no idea what was happening in anyone's life. I, I begged my parents for it back, but they didn't care one bit. But then Friday came. I was looking out the window and saw Brody in Chloe's backyard. I instantly started fuming. I wanted to jump out and go yell at him right there, but my parents would kill me. But then came my perfect opportunity. As I was crying, my dad knocked on my door. He told me he and mom were going out to dinner, and they'd know if I left. You are not to leave your room. We'll know if you do. But here's what they didn't know. When dad installed those motion sensors, he missed something. My bedroom window had an old storm shutter that swung out instead of

You discover your perfect marriage was everyone's nightmare. Growing up, I wanted to be just like my mom, even if that meant being sold at 16, bred like livestock and learning to smile when my husband brought home other women's perfume on his clothes. My mother taught me these things were badges of honour, proof that we were good women who understood our place in the world. She would sit me down at her vanity mirror and brush my hair while telling me stories of my grandmother who raised 14 children from three different women her husband kept and how she never once complained or showed jealousy because that was weakness. When I turn 16, my parents arranged my marriage to a 23 year old doctor and I felt chosen, special and better than my cousins who were matched with farmers and merchants. My mother cried happy tears at the ceremony while whispering in my ear that I was fulfilling my destiny, that my grandmother would be so proud to see me continuing our family's legacy of strength. The wedding night came with pain that made me bite through my lip. But my mother had warned me this was normal, that the blood on the sheets was proof of my purity and worth. My husband was kind compared to what I've been taught to expect, never raising his hand to me, never forcing himself on me after I got pregnant with when our parents demanded grandchildren immediately and we complied. Because that's what good children did. But after five encounters that left me sobbing into my pillow, he promised never to touch me again if I didn't want it. I thought this made him the best husband in the world. And I told my mother about his kindness, how lucky I was that he respected my wishes. She smiled and said I was blessed that most men wouldn't be so understanding. When we moved to Canada after I turned 18, he asked my permission to see other women for his needs. And I grant did it proudly, thinking this made me enlightened and mature. My mother had done the same for my father. My aunts all knew about their husband's arrangements. So I called my mother to tell her how well I was handling marriage. She praised me for being so wise, understanding that men had needs wives couldn't always fulfill. The jealousy was a poison that destroyed families. Every Friday night, he would leave after putting our sons to bed and I would clean the house and feel accomplished like I was winning at being a wife. And Covid arrived and changed everything. I got so sick I could barely breathe. And for over a month, he became someone I'd never seen before. He held my hair when I vomited, changed my sheets when I sweated through them, sang Lullaby.

He turned down my proposal twice, so I walked away. Two years later, I walked in with someone that left her completely speechless. Britney said no twice. First time at our college graduation. I'm not ready for marriage, I want to travel. Second time a year later at her birthday dinner. You're sweet, but I need someone more ambitious. That word stung. Ambitious. Like our four years together meant nothing. Two weeks later, she was Instagram official with Logan, my former best friend since high school. Trust fund kid with a BMW his daddy bought and a marketing empire that was actually his uncle's firm. They flaunted it everywhere. Expensive restaurants I couldn't afford, designer clothes. Constant vacation posts to places I've never seen. Our entire friend group acted like it was destiny, not betrayal. They just make sense together. They'd say I was crushed, but channeled everything into medical school applications. Took out massive loans, moved three states away, and disappeared into 18 hour study days. No social media, no dating. for focus on becoming the surgeon I'd always dreamed of being. While I was killing myself in organic chemistry and anatomy labs, Brittany and Logan were living their best life. Engaged after six months, with a ring that cost more than my entire tuition. The wedding was planned for some Vineyard in Napa. Two years into my surgery residency at Children's Hospital, I met Lily at a pediatric trauma conference. She. I was presenting research on Emergency interventions. Brilliant. Passionate about saving kids lives. We talked for hours about everything except medicine. She made me laugh for the first time in years. Eight months of dating before she casually mentioned having an older brother. He's kind of a mess. Living off our parents at 30, dating this girl who thinks she's too good for everyone. When she said his name was Logan, my blood ran cold. When she showed me his Instagram, there was Britney posing with my replacement life. Wait. Hey, Lily said. Noticing my reaction, you know them? I told her everything. Instead of being upset, Lily started laughing. Oh, my god, you're that Noah. Britney talks about her boring ex who became a doctor at every family dinner. She has no idea we're together. Logan complains that she keeps comparing him to some guy who actually did something with his life. Fast forward to my little sister's wedding.
NA

Bought a house without telling my parents, and later found they'd promised my home to my sister's whole family. The revelation came during what was supposed to be a Celebration dinner at my childhood home, where I'd planned to share my exciting news about finally achieving homeownership at 28. Instead, I walked into a nightmare orchestrated by the people who were supposed to love me most. My sister Jessica sat at the head of the dining table like she owned the place, her husband Mark beside her, with their twin boys climbing all over the furniture while my parents beamed at them like they just announced the cure for cancer. The moment I stepped through that familiar front door, Jessica's eyes lit up with malicious glee as she announced, mom and dad have the most wonderful news about your little house situation, Emma. The words hit me like ice water as my mother clasped her hands together, practically vibrating with excitement. Oh, Emma, we've solved everything. Jessica needs more space for the boys, and since you bought that house all by yourself without even asking our opinion, we figured you must not really need our help or approval for anything. My father nodded approvingly, completely oblivious to the trap they just walked into. We told Jessica's family they could move in with you next month. It's perfect. You'll have help with the mortgage, and the boys will have a yard to play in. Family should stick together. After all, the Crystal wine glass in my hand trembled as Jessica leaned back in her chair, savoring every second of my shot. What none of them knew was that they just made the biggest miscalculation of their lives. And I was about to show them exactly what happened when they under

I asked my brother not to bring his girlfriend to my wedding. My brother Jake has this girlfriend named Becca who literally cannot stand not being the centre of attention for 5 minutes. Every family dinner, every holiday, every gathering, she finds a way to make it about her. Last Thanksgiving, she announced she was pregnant right when my dad was about to carve the Turkey. Turns out she wasn't even pregnant. Just wanted to see everyone's reactions. So when I was planning my wedding to my fiance, Ryan, I knew I had to do something about the Becca situation. This was going to be my one day, the one day that was supposed to be about me and Ryan starting our life together. I called Jake about three months before the wedding. Hey, so about the wedding, I started. I need to ask you something kind of awkward. What's up, he said. And I could hear him eating cereal in the background. I really don't want Becca there. I know that sounds harsh, but she always makes everything about herself and I just can't deal with that stress on my wedding day. The line went quiet for like 10 seconds and Jake exploded. Are you serious right now you're uninviting my girlfriend from your wedding? I'm not uninviting her because she was never invited in the first place. The invitation was just for you. That's the same thing. We've been together for two years. She's basically family. I tried To explain that it wasn't personal, that I just wanted one drama free day. But Jake wasn't having it. He said if Becca couldn't come, then he wouldn't come either. I told him that was his choice. Hope think he changed his mind? He didn't. But here's where it gets crazy. The day of my wedding, I'm getting my makeup done in the bridal suite when my cousin Madison bursts in. Uh, you need to see this, he says, shoving her phone in my face. It's Becca's Instagram story. She's posted like 15 videos of herself getting all dressed up, doing her makeup, picking out jewellery. The caption on the last one says, can't wait to celebrate love today with a bunch of heart emojis and the location tagged as our wedding venue. My heart drops. She's coming anyway, Madison.

Dad wants to try me before the wedding. Two nights before my wedding, Marcus and I were sitting on our apartment floor folding programs and sipping wine when he said so casually, tomorrow night my father needs to examine you. I blinked. Sorry, what? He looked at me like I'd forgotten the salad for dinner. It's a family tradition. My brothers and Uncle Roberto will be there, too. Just takes a few minutes. I laughed because what else do you do when someone says something that insane? Marcus wasn't laughing. His face stayed dead serious. He reached for my hand, started rubbing circles in my palm like he always did to calm me. It's how we make sure the bride is pure, he said. I couldn't wrap my head around it. We were sitting in our candlelit apartment, rsvp cards and neat stacks. Honey Moon to Santorini already booked. And now he wanted his dad to inspect me with witnesses. I asked if his mom had done it. He nodded. Every woman who marries into the Castano family does. My mom, Maria, all my cousin's wives. It proves your love, shows your honest. That was the moment the warmth I'd felt from his family flipped into something colder than ice. His mom, the woman who comforted me when my grandma died, who taught me how to make her Sunday sauce, she went through this. I yanked my hand away. No, that's not happening. He looked crushed. Like I just told Him I cheated on him or something. You don't understand, he said. It's not some violation. Tradition verification, just five minutes, then it's done. Now I understood why he'd insisted we wait. I thought it was sweet. Turned out it was about preserving me like some ancient relic, so I could be verified by his dad.

Girlfriend texted, I think we should break up as a test. So I replied, I agree, your stuff will be on your porch in an hour. Her response was desperate and confused. Wait, it was just a joke. But I was serious. I was at my desk when my phone buzzed. Alexis, Ryan, I think we should break up. This isn't working anymore. Most guys would panic and start frantically calling, but I felt pure relief, like I just sat down a weight I've been carrying for months. This wasn't the first time Alexis had pulled this move. This was her specialty. When she didn't get her way last month because I couldn't take a random Wednesday off work for her friend's party, maybe we're just not compatible. Before that, because I suggested we split her 300 dollar birthday dinner. I guess I know where I stand with you now. Each time I begged, blamed, reassured her promise to do better. Each time she'd graciously forgive me like she was doing me a massive favor. I just need to know you care, she'd say with those fake tears. The pattern was predictable. Something wouldn't go her way, she'd threaten the relationship. I scramble to fix it, repeat. But this time I typed back, I agree your stuff will be on your porch in an hour. The response was immediate. My phone started buzzing. Wait, what? Followed by Ryan, that's not what I meant. And crying emojis. Then came the kicker. I was testing you to see if you'd fight for us. Real boyfriends don't just give up that easily. There it was, the truth. She'd never admitted she'd been testing me. All those fights, all those threats were experiments to see how much control she had. Every. Maybe we should break up. With psychological warfare disguised as relationship communication, I drove home and packed her belongings, seven boxes and four garbage bags that had gradually taken over my.

What's the worst parenting you've witnessed? I was dating this guy Mark for about six months when he finally introduced me to his 8 year old daughter Emma. He'd always made excuses about why I couldn't meet her. She was shy, going through a phase staying with grandparents. Red flags I ignored because I was falling for him. The first time I went to his house, Emma answered the door. She was this tiny, timid little thing who immediately apologized for existing. Sorry, sorry. I'll get daddy. Sorry for bothering you. Mark came to the door and didn't even acknowledge her. No hug, no how was your day? Nothing. He just disappeared upstairs like a ghost. During dinner, Emma asked quietly if she could have some ketchup. Mark exploded. You always want something. Can't you just eat normal food like a normal kid? This is why your mother left. I watched this little girl's face crumble. She whispered, sorry, daddy, and ate her plain chicken in silence while tears rolled down her cheeks. I tried to lighten the mood, asking Emma about school. Mark cut me off. She's not good at talking to people. Emma, go to your room. Adults are trying to have a conversation. She vanished again. I didn't see her the rest of the night. Over the next few weeks, I started noticing a pattern. Emma would try to exist quietly, but Mark treated her like an inconvenience he was stuck with. One day I came over. Early and heard him screaming at her upstairs. You're just like your worthless mother. Nothing but problems. I found Emma sobbing in her room, which was basically a storage closet with a mattress on the floor. No decorations, no toys, no signs a child lived there. The breaking point came during Emma's birthday. Mark forgot completely. When I reminded him, he got annoyed and said birthdays are just made up holidays to make kids feel special. She needs to learn the world doesn't revolve around her. I could.

I never met my wife's family because she cut them out of her life. She told me early on that her dad was a nightmare. Not just strict or distant, but the kind of man who made home feel like a prison. She never went into details, just that the day she left for college was the day she finally felt free. After that, she never looked back. Years passed. And then one day, her mom reached out. She said her dad had changed, but he regretted everything and wanted to make things right. My wife was skeptical, but her mom kept pushing, telling her he was a different man now. She wanted to believe it. I could see it in the way she hesitated when she talked about it. Eventually, she agreed to let him back in. At first, things were fine. He was polite, maybe even a little quiet. He brought over groceries, asked about her work, kept his distance. She told me he seemed softer, like age had worn him down. I wanted to believe that, too. Then one night, I came home from work, and everything fell off. The second I walked through the door, she was sitting at the kitchen table, arms wrapped around herself, looking smaller than I had ever seen her. She wouldn't look at me. That's when I saw them. Bruises. One on her arm, another dark and swelling along her cheekbone. I felt my stomach drop. I stepped closer. What happened? She shook her head. I don't wanna talk about it. I stared at her, waiting for her to say something, anything that would make this make sense. But she wouldn't even meet my eyes. I already knew. I turned and grabbed my keys. I found him at the same bar he always went to.

My cousin thought he owned the family legacy. So I destroyed his moment in front of everyone. In my family, there's one name that matters more than anything, the business. My grandpa started it from nothing, just a wrench, a truck and ridiculous work ethic. Now it's this big local empire, auto shops, property, even a commercial fleet. But since I was a kid, everyone said my cousin Nathan would take it over. He was the heir, the one with the polished handshake, the church smile, the button down shirts with his initials on the cuff. And me, I was hands on the grease stained. Stay out of the photos cousin. Didn't matter that I worked every summer there, Learned the books, showed up before the sun. If Nathan showed up once a month in a collard shirt, they acted like he was royalty. But I stayed quiet. I told myself, just work hard, it'll pay off. Then last year, Grandpa passed and suddenly everyone's talking succession. Nathan starts calling himself Next Gen CEO before there's even a will reading, starts inviting investors over to Grandpa's house. Post a photo of Grandpa's office with the caption, big shoes to fill, legacy continues. I snapped. I knew Grandpa better than anyone. I knew what he really thought about Nathan, the flashy spending, the fake smile, the way he dodged real work. So I went digging. One night I stayed late in the office, dug through Grandpa's old file cabinet, found something Interesting. A USB drive on it. A video Grandpa sitting at his desk filmed a month before he died. He starts talking, really talking. Not about Nate.

What's the world's strangest job that actually exists? When I was 24, I was hired as a professional shoplifter. Essentially my job was to go into big name stores such as Walmart or target and try to shoplift as much as possible. I then walk out of the store and report to the manager explaining everything I had stolen. I would do this so I could tell them the weak points in their security system and how they could potentially upgrade. They then pay me my base salary and I got to take home whatever items I had managed to steal as my bonus. I remember one specific day on the job I stole a full blown TV. I wanted to go to the manager and let him know his security system was the worst I had ever seen. I couldn't find it. So there I was walking around with a huge plasma TV in my arms with the price tag still on it, when one of the employees told me they last saw the manager sneaking out to the parking lot. And so I walked out too. The employee didn't even try to stop me, despite it being obvious I hadn't paid for the TV either way. I went down into the lot and when I did, I heard a woman yelping from across the lot. I followed the sound and what I saw made me gag. It was the manager I've been looking for. Getting some brain from A questionably legal looking employee. The worst part is that the girl refused to stop. I asked her to at least give me a second so I could talk to the manager, but she said no, she needed a promotion. And so I stood there with a huge TV in my hands and had a chat with the manager about how bad his security system was. All the while he was animalistically grunting with his pants down about how good this girl's head game was. And I'm ashamed to say it, but I developed a rager in the process.

What did you do when you realized your daughter was being abused? I came home early from work with a headache, expecting the house to be empty since my teenage daughter Georgia had cheer practice. But instead I heard voices upstairs. I was about to call up when I heard her say, please stop, you're hurting me. Everything inside me went cold. Then came her boyfriend, Paxton's voice, low and menacing. You embarrassed me in front of my friends today. The sound of a slap echoed through the house, follow by my daughter crying. I ran up those stairs and burst through her bedroom door. Paxton had Georgia backed against the dresser, his hand around her throat. The second he saw me, he dropped his hand and stepped back like nothing had happened. Missus Johnson. We were just. I cut him off. Get out of my house now. He looked confused, putting on that innocent act. I was just helping Georgia with. Get out, I scream. He grabbed his backpack and left, but not before whispering something to Georgia that made her face go white. The moment he was gone, I turned to Georgia. Her face was red and swollen from crying, finger shaped bruises already forming on her throat. Georgia, what the hell was that? She immediately started making excuses. Mom, we were just playing around. He wasn't really hurting me. But I could see the fear in her eyes. Playing around. He had his hand around Your throat. She broke down completely, then sliding down the wall until she was sitting on the floor, sobbing through her tears. She told me everything, how it had started with him grabbing her arm too hard when he was angry, how it escalated to slapping and pushing, how he convinced her it was her fault. He threatened to kill himself if she ever left him. Told her that no one would believe her because he was so perfect. Felt completely trapped, especially with homecoming just three days away and the entire school expecting them to be crowned king and queen. She begged me not to call the police, convinced that no one would believe her. They'll say I'm lying, she sobbed. Everyone loves him. They'll think I'm crazy. That's when the idea hit me. What if we didn't have to convince anyone? I said, what if we made him show everyone exactly who he really is? I explained my plan. It was risky, but she was desperate enough to try anything. On homecoming night, she got ready like nothing had changed. When Paxton picked her up, he was back to his charming self, acting like nothing had happened. Sorry about the other day, Missus Johnson. Georgia and I were just.

Scariest thing a family member has ever told you. I was 23 when my family decided it was time for me to collect my first wife. They already had her picked out. My 13 year old cousin Fatima, whose mother bragged about her early development. You see, every girl in my family knew the rule. The day you get your first period was the day you got married. It didn't matter whether you still played with dolls or couldn't reach the kitchen counter. If you could bleed, you could breed. I was nine when I watched my oldest brother, Ahmed, get married to his first wife on his 21st birthday. She was 12 years old. By the time I was 15, Achmed had buried that first wife and was on to his third pregnancy complications. Everyone said your wife's youth was like a currency. Whichever man had the youngest, most obedient wife was the most praised in society. Family gatherings, my uncles would compete like kids comparing prizes. Amina was only 11 when I claimed her. Uncle Kareem would boast, holding up her photo. In response, Uncle Hassan would lean back, working. That's nothing. I got my Osman at 10 and she still had her baby teeth. The jewelry shop didn't even make wedding rings that small. For years, I played along, smiling when they discussed my future, agreeing that 14 was getting too old for a bride. Inside, my stomach turned. But what could I do? Speaking against it, Meant exile of you and all the women in the family. Three months before my wedding date, I found harifatima, my wife, to be in our family's utility room with a bottle of bleach. Her hands were shaking so bad she couldn't open it. When she saw me, she dropped to her knees. Please don't tell. Please. I can't. I know what happens. I've seen what happens. I took the bottle, sat on the floor next to her, and for the first time in my life, I said out loud, I know. I don't want this either. She sat there with her mouth wide open, staring at me like I had five heads. Suddenly, she lunged at me for a hug. Can you please tell them I'm crazy? Tell them I'm possessed or cursed. They won't want me if I'm insane. Bad blood ruins the lineage. That sentence changed everything. Because she was right. My family obsessed over bloodlines, genetic purity, producing perfect sons. Mental illness was the ultimate contamination. I'd seen them reject marriage proposals over rumors of a great aunt who talked to walls. Within a week, I taught Fatima to twitch at dinner tables, mumbling numbers in corners, scratching symbols on her arms with her fingernails. I coached her through episodes, taught her to roll her eyes back in gibberish, and claimed she saw demons in the wallpaper. She put on such an award winning act that sometimes even I was disturbed. My mother was horrified. She Was perfect. Two weeks ago, she wailed to my father. Now look at her. What if it spreads to the children? The wedding was quietly postponed. Words spread through the girl cousins like wildfire. My sister Amira, 14 and recently bloomed, came to me next. Then her friend. Nor then, nor sister. Before I knew it, I was running midnight coaching sessions in my car, teaching girls how to manifest madness. Dead eyes are crucial, I'd instruct. Stare through people, not at them. Laugh at nothing. Cry without reason. But timing is everything. Save the worst episodes for when marriage talks begin. Some girls were naturals. My cousin Layla developed a fictional friend she'd have full conversations with during family gatherings. She'd serve tea to empty chairs holding invisible children. Her father postponed three marriage proposals, terrified of producing defective grandchildren. Others needed more work. Soft spoken, Miriam couldn't sell the performance until I taught her to channel her real terror into fake hysteria. Think about your wedding night, I tell her. Now scream. The sound she made convinced everyone. But in six months, we had a full network. 15 marriageable girls, all displaying various forms of borderline schizophrenia. Family meetings turned to chaos as girls would trigger each other. One would start humming, another would begin rocking. Suddenly, three were speaking in unison about visions of black water. The elders panicked. They brought in healers who charged fortunes to wave incense around, doctors who prescribed sedatives, religious leaders who Performed exorcisms that left the girls even more convincingly traumatized. I thought we could maintain it indefinitely. The girls were protecting each other. Older ones coaching younger ones as they came of age. We had a system. And my family may have been PDF files, but they weren't stupid. So after a year of failed cures, they started noticing patterns. How the madness only struck marriageable girls. How symptoms peaked during wedding seasons. How I somehow was always nearby when episodes occurred. The final gathering happened on a Thursday. 23 of us were at my uncle's house for his daughter's engagement. The plan was to have her fake her worst episode yet. But when my uncle called her forward to receive her engagement blessing, she looked.

Oh, nothing. Just a hobby of mine. What the hell is the hobby? Is it to piss people off? Oh, ha ha. How did you even get my number? I asked the landlord. He said he's asked you many times, but you keep doing it. Well, I always stop when I'm asked to, but it's something I need to do. It's 1:00am. Do it sometime else. You're right. I'm really sorry. You should be. Don't make me have to come up there myself. I won't. Hey. Oh, sorry. I'll stop. I thought I was okay since it's early in the day. No, no, you're fine. I'm not that big of a Karen. Haha. Why did you text me then? I don't know. I guess I was just being curious on what you're doing. A bit nosy, don't you think? Alright, maybe. What's your name? Josh. And you? Jessica. Oh, oh, what? Nothing. Oh, come on. You can't say that and then not tell me it's the name of a girl I know. Well, I'm better than her. You can't be better than someone who's already perfect. Oh, wow. She's perfect. Who is this girl? My girlfriend. Girlfriend. Oh my God. Is that what the noise is? I should have known. Oh, Jessica. No, that is Not it she's well, not even around anymore. You guys broke up. Why do you still call her your girlfriend? Well, the thing is we never broke up. She sort of just, I don't know, left. Oh, I'm sorry to hear that, but that just means she wasn't the right one for you. Anyways, can we talk about something else? Yeah, sure. How much longer will you be making this noise for? I might invest in some earplugs. It's not that bad. Stop it. But tomorrow should be the last day. Well, let me just say I'm excited to finally get some peace. Well, I'm glad. Anyways, I'm gonna get back to work talk tomorrow maybe. Uh oh my God, it's getting louder by the minute. Sorry, I'll tone it down a bit. Oh my God. What is it that you are doing that is so important but yet you can't tell me? Why do you need to know so bad? I don't need to know. I just wanna know because you are the only person making this type of noise in the complex. I'm surprised everyone isn't complaining about you and I told you I'm almost done. After that, you won't need to hear from me again. Oh my. Alright, just finish up. It's 8:00 you have an hour. Okay, and gosh, turn off that music. Sounds like a screeching cat. What? No way you can listen to that. I have to. You don't understand. You're so annoying. Okay. Today's the day you told me you would be finished. I will in a couple of hours. at least going to show me what the hell it is that you've been doing all this time? I could, but you have to promise not to make fun of it. Sure. I mean, I think I've already made fun of you enough. True. Alright, let me get back to work. I'll text you when I'm done. Sure. Alright, I'm done. Oh my God. Finally, this better be good and for a good reason. Otherwise, you annoyed me for nothing. Well, do you remember when I told you about my girlfriend? You can now check part 2 by pressing share. Then more.
