The worst thing your parents made you believe. When I was 12 years old, my mother slit her wrist in front of me because I asked to go to a friend's birthday party. And as she bled into our kitchen sink, she made me promise I'd never try to leave her again. She survived that time, barely. While the paramedics worked on her, she gripped my hand with bloody fingers and whispered, this is what happens when you abandon me. I spent three days in the hospital chapel, 13 years old and convinced. I almost murdered my mother by wanting to go to a sleepover. When she came home, arm bandaged and eyes hollow, she made me sleep in her bed so she could hold on to me all night. I need to know you're here, she said. Otherwise, the darkness comes back. The rules formed quickly after that. I couldn't join clubs because staying late at school feels like you're choosing them over me. I couldn't have friends over because their energy disrupts our bond. Each boundary came with the same threat, sometimes spoken, sometimes just a gesture toward her scarred wrists. She kept razors displayed on the bathroom counter like weapons, reminding me what would happen if I, I broke her heart again. By 14, I was homeschooled and completely isolated. Mom said it was better this way, just us two against a world that didn't understand our connection. She'd have good days where she'd braid my hair. And we'd watch movies and I think maybe this was enough. But then I mentioned wanting to learn to drive someday. And she'd go silent. She'd lock herself in the bathroom and I'd sit outside the door begging her to come out. She'd emerge hours later showing me fresh cuts on her thighs. Practice cuts. Call them for when you finally abandoned me for real. I attempted my first real escape at 15. I found a youth shelter address at the library and memorized it. One night while mom slept, I packed a bag and made it to the front door. But she was sitting in the dark living room waiting. I felt you pulling away, she said calmly. Then she swallowed an entire bottle of sleeping pills in front of me. I called 9 1 1 and rode with her to the hospital holding her hand while they pumped her stomach. When she woke up, she smiled sadly. You did this, she said, but at least you stayed to watch. After that, she installed bells on my bedroom door and windows. She test me randomly, pretending to hurt herself to see if I try to leave or just save her. I always chose to save her, but I was dying inside, suffocating under the weight of keeping her alive. I started writing goodbye letters I never send, hiding them in my textbooks. I tried to get away again when I was sixteen. Mom had fallen asleep after taking anxiety Medication. And I thought I had time. I made it three blocks before a police car pulled up. Mom had called them claiming I was mentally unstable. She'd shown them my hidden letters as evidence. As they drove me home, she texted me, if you'd kept going, you would have found my body when you came back. I had the bath ready that night. She showed me a new scar on her stomach. I did this while you were gone, she said. She made me help her bandage it, narrating how she would have cut deeper if I made it another block. Next time you leave, she promised, I'll make sure I time it perfectly. You'll be free, but you'll be a murderer. I became. I'm hyper vigilant, watching for signs she was spiraling. My entire existence became keeping her from the edge. When I caught her standing on our apartment balcony at 3:00am, I didn't ask why. I just took her hand and let her back to bed. But then I got a scholarship to art school. Mom found the acceptance letter before I could hide it. She didn't say anything, just disappeared into the bathroom. I heard water running and pounded on the door. When she finally.

I only go to black salons. I know that sounds weird coming from a white girl, but hear me out. This whole thing started about three years ago when I was living in Atlanta for my internship. My usual salon back home was like four hours away and I was desperate for a trim because my hair looked like I stuck my finger in an electrical socket. My roommate, Keisha, was getting ready to head out to her salon and saw me struggling with my massive curls in the bathroom mirror. She, I just laughed and said, girl, come with me. My stylist will sort you out. I was hesitant because I'd never been to a black salon before. But honestly, my hair was so bad I would have tried anything. Walking into that salon was like entering a whole different world. The energy was incredible. Everyone was talking, laughing, music playing, kids running around while their moms got their hair done. It felt alive in a way that the quiet, sterile salons I was used to never did. The stylist, Miss Janet, took one look at my hair and shook her head, baby, who's been cutting your hair? Because they need to stop. She started running her fingers through it, asking me about my routine, what products I used, how I dried it. Nobody had ever asked me those questions before. They just wet it, cut it and send me on my way. Miss Janet spent two hours on My hair, two hours. She deep conditioned it, trimmed each curl individually, showed me how to scrunch it properly and sent me home with specific instructions about what products to use and how often to wash it. My hair looked better than it ever had in my entire life. But here's the thing that really got me. She charged me $40. 40. The salon back home charged.

Friend's father said I couldn't protect his daughter until I protected his entire livelihood. My girlfriend had been nervous about introducing me to her family for weeks, warning me that her father built their ranch into one of the Southwest's premier cattle operations and didn't trust outsiders. I brushed off her concerns, figuring any family who raised someone as amazing as her couldn't be that bad. Fighting over some cattle ranchers seemed manageable for someone who'd grown up working his grandfather's ranch before heading to college. Anyway, the ranch sprawled across thousands of acres with cattle worth more than most houses, and her father's handshake could have crushed walnuts while his eyes cataloged everything from my soft leather shoes to my unmarked hands. The moment I mentioned working in marketing, his smile turned predatory. Marketing, huh? He said while looking me up and down. Well, I guess somebody has to make a living pushing paper while real men do actual work. The dismissal stung, but I forced to smile because this dinner meant everything to my girlfriend. Her father carved brisket while zeroing in on my supposed ignorance about their world. So you probably think steak comes from the steak tree and chocolate milk comes from brown cows, he said with a laugh that made my skin crawl. His brother joined in chuckling. Bet this city boy couldn't tell a bull from a steer if his life depended on it. Has he ever even seen a live cow before today? The family erupted in laughter at my supposed cluelessness about their world while I sat there like a museum exhibit. But I kept quiet because my girlfriend was already shifting uncomfortably in her seat. His wife turned it up a notch when she noticed me not saying anything. Oh my, look at those soft little hands! She cooed while refilling my glass, practically jiggling. I bet you've never lifted anything heavier than a briefcase, have you, sweetie? Do you get manicures, too? Most women don't even take that good care of their nails. Her sons were cracking up now, one adding between laughs, he probably uses more beauty products than his girlfriend does. The laughter felt like knives as they questioned my very manhood, but I swallowed my pride because causing a scene would only embarrass my girlfriend further. You know what kills me? Her dad continued, wiping tears from laughing so hard. Marketing coordinator probably makes, what, 25 grand? If he's lucky? That's what we pay our teenage ranch hands for summer work. The whole table was howling now as his brother added, our daughter could marry a successful rancher and live in a mansion, but instead she's settling for someone who will be renting apartments and driving used cars his whole life. She'll be clipping coupons while her friends are taking vacations. My girlfriend's face went crimson as her own family treated our future like a pathetic joke. He called me pale as a ghost and said I Probably weigh less than most of their calves. He laughed as he said, I'd probably never thrown a punch in my life. His eldest son was practically wheezing with laughter as he said, I look like a strong wind would blow me over. What really got to me was him telling everyone, what happens when our daughter needs a real man to protect her? Is he gonna bore the burglar to death with marketing statistics? The entire family dissolved into hysterics while I watched my girlfriend's face crumble. Her own family systematically destroying every aspect of my worth as a potential partner. Every instinct screamed at me to defend us both, but I bit my tongue because any reaction would only give them more ammunition. That's when a young girl burst through the back door screaming, daddy, something's wrong with thunder! His belly looks like a balloon! The men jumped up, but I was already sprinting toward the barn. My body operating on instincts buried for over a decade. Their million dollar bull

How did you put a spoiled brat in their place? My girlfriend was so insane that she told everyone that we broke up because I cheated on her in her dream. She was a spoiled, rich girl who came from a terrible snobby family. They were the kind of people who would wipe their butts with hundred dollar bills if they ran out of toilet paper. If she and I ever got into an argument, she would run back to her daddy who would send her on a week long vacation to Cancun just so she could recover from our arguments. In one of these week long vacations to Cancun, she ended up getting pregnant from one of the six hotel staff she cheated on me with. But when she came back, instead of telling me, she told me that she was breaking up with me because she had a dream in Mexico that I would cheat on her point. I was so over the relationship that I didn't care if it ended. After I moved out and moved back to my parents house, I got a call from an anonymous number. When I picked up the phone, it was my ex girlfriend's father. He called to say, you broke my baby girl's heart, now I'm going to break your head. I'd sleep with one eye open if I were you. I told him whatever and for him and his crazy family to leave me alone. Truthfully, I was scared. I knew he had enough money to hire whoever he wanted to do whatever he wanted. When I applied for a new job, I noticed someone was watching me at the office. They weren't just watching me, they were staring. When I left the building, I saw them following behind. I started to look around and that's when I saw a black van with two men inside it also watching me. I've seen enough movies to know what that meant. So I didn't waste any time. I started running as fast as I could. I ended up running into a park where I found a police officer. I alerted him and told him that I was being followed by three men. I thought that he would help me, but instead he told me to put my hands behind my back and that I was being arrested. I demanded that he tell me why I was being arrested, but he told me to shut my broke ass up. The second he called me broke, I realized that this was all my ex's fault. I was doing, he paid the cop off to arrest me. At this point, I didn't even fight back. The cop put me in his cop car and just as I thought, he brought me to my ex girlfriend's estate. When he threw me out of the car, my girlfriend's father was waiting for me, sipping tea like a James Bond villain. I asked him if he was Going to take my life away. And all he said was, we need to talk. I followed him inside and passed by my girlfriend who was getting her feet done. Her father sat me down and there was trembling in his voice, my babe.

I adopted a dog after I thought my boyfriend broke up with me. My boyfriend Jake and I had been together for like 8 months and things were going pretty well. Then one Tuesday morning I get this text from him that just says, I think we need to talk about us. This isn't working anymore. I literally felt my stomach drop. I'm sitting there in my pajamas eating cereal before work and this dude just dumps me over text. I tried calling him but it went straight to voicemail. I texted back asking if we could talk in person, but he left me on read. By lunchtime, I was convinced it was over. My coworker Ashley was like, girl, you need a rebound. But honestly, I wasn't ready for that. Instead, I did something way more impulsive. I drove to the animal shelter after work that same day. I've been wanting a dog for years, but Jake was always like, we're not ready for that responsibility. Well, guess what, Jake? Now I don't need your permission. There was this 3 year old golden retriever mix named Buddy who'd been there for two months. The shelter lady said his previous family had to give him up because they were moving overseas. He was the sweetest thing, just sitting there wagging his tail at everyone who walked by. I filled out all the paperwork and paid the adoption fee right there. Two hundred bucks later, I'm driving home with a dog. In my backseat. I spent the entire evening at Petsmart buying everything, dog bed, toys, food, bowls, leash, collar, the works. Dropped like $400. Easy. Posted a bunch of Instagram stories with Buddy, captioned them stuff like new roommate and fresh start vibes. I was actually feeling pretty good about the whole thing. The next morning, Jake shows up at my apartment with coffee and bagels from our usual spot. I open the door and Buddy immediately runs up to him, tail going crazy. Jake's face is just pure confusion. He's like, whose dog is this? And I'm like, mine, obviously. Then he gets this weird look and asks why I got a dog. I told him it was.

What made a female patient refuse all the male doctors in the building? The first thing I noticed when I entered the patient's room was her deep sunken eyes and pale cracked lips. I approached her cautiously, remembering how the charge nurse warned the girl refused all male staff. We all knew what that meant. And she looked as broken as I imagined. I pulled up a chair next to her bed instead of standing over her and gently asked if she wanted some water first. She nodded. Sweetie, you're safe here, I said, keeping my voice soft like I do with my anxious patients. Male staff won't come near you, I promise. It's just us girls here. She looked at me for the first time and whispered, he's here. I asked who. And at first she refused to even say his name. I handed her my pen and clipboard. After a second, her hand moved. Percy. My blood boiled at the name. He was my everything, she finally whispered and started showing me photos on her phone of them together at college, confirming that it was the same Percy who was now a resident at the hospital. I did everything for him, everything. Her voice cracked as she swiped to screenshots of assignments, time stamps showing her submit his biochemistry homework at 3:00am, his pathology essays at 4:00am, his anatomy exams that she taken for him. She showed me his Instagram from those same nights, him doing beer pong And body shots with other girls while she was writing his thesis, this on cellular biology. The day after graduation, after I'd spent three years making sure he got into residency, he sent me this, she said, and handed me her phone. The text made me want to throw something. Babe, you're too clingy and it's honestly suffocating. I need to focus on my career without distractions. And honestly, doctors are supposed to date doctors and you're not one. We're done. Please don't contact me again. I waited until she was stable and sleeping before I stormed into the break room where three other nurses were charting. You guys are never going to believe what I just found out about Percy, I said. I told them everything and watch their faces go from confused to furious. And within 10 minutes, we had half the female staff crammed into that tiny break room. I knew something was off when he asked me to explain what antibiotics were said. June from pediatrics and Sydney are attending walked in right as someone said we should report him. And she closed the door behind her. Actually, I've been documenting his knowledge gaps for weeks, she said, pulling out her phone to show us pages of notes. But this explains everything. The room went quiet while we all looked at each other. And then Lida from the ICU said what we were all thinking, ladies, we don't need to destroy him. We just need to Let him destroy himself while we enjoy every second of it. The plan rolled out so naturally. It was almost beautiful to watch. Percy started getting paid for every.

The moment that made you hate your birthday. When I turned 8, my parents threw me this huge party. All my friends came. We had a bouncy house, pizza, the works. I felt like the luckiest kid in the world. But right as we were about to cut my Ninja Turtles cake, my mom pulled me aside with this panicked look. Honey, we need to tell everyone to go home right now. Daddy is very sick and needs to go to the hospital. I was devastated. My friends left confused, some crying because they thought someone was dying. The bouncy house guy packed up while I sat there in my party hat watching my perfect day crumble. Dad spent three days in the hospital for what they said was a severe stomach infection. I felt so guilty for being upset about my ruined party when he was suffering. But this became a pattern. Every single birthday for the next 10 years, some crisis would strike right before or during my Celebration. When I turned 9, my mom got food poisoning an hour before my sleepover. When I turned 10, my grandma fell down the stairs during my bowling party. 11 was my dad's appendix acting up. 12 was our car breaking down on the way to the amusement park. By 13, I started having panic attacks before my birthday. I'd wake up wondering what disaster would ruin it this time. My friends stopped expecting invitations. Some parents whispered that our Family was cursed or unlucky. I began asking for quiet celebrations instead. Just cake at home, please. But even then, something always went wrong. The power would go out, someone would get injured. There was always something. When I turned 16, I didn't even want to party. I just wanted to go to dinner with my parents. But halfway through appetizers, my mom clutched her chest. I think I'm having heart palpitations. I started telling people I hated birthdays. Friends thought I was being dramatic. Just bad luck, they'd say. By 17, I was seeing a therapist for what I thought was birthday anxiety disorder. She kept asking about my family dynamics, but I defended them. They can't help that emergencies happen. When I turned 18, I didn't even tell them it was my birthday. I was planning to just let it pass quietly, maybe treat myself to coffee later. But that afternoon, I came home early from school and overheard my parents on the phone with my aunt.

My spoiled half sister wanted to show up in a wedding dress to my engagement party, so I changed the party theme so she would fit right in. My half sister, Heather and I never really got along. It doesn't help that Heather's mom hates me and my mom. She has always tried to one up me. She thinks she is better than me and tells all our cousins that I am insecure because my dad chose their family over my mom and me. She never fails to make all my life events all about her. Like my graduation party where she announced that she was accepted into a prestigious university. Now, my fiance and I got engaged last month and had our engagement party this Saturday. We had planned it originally as a casual formal event. Nice dresses, but not I am going to the Met Gala nice. More like we are going to a good restaurant nice. Anyway, my cousin hits me up saying she has to show me something. It was the picture of the dress Heather was gonna wear. This dress. Jesus Christ. It can only be described as opulent. It was long and white, strapless, with sewn in crystals and golden accents. I'm pretty sure it's a wedding dress, but I can't be 100%. This made me really mad. I started texting people telling them that there had been a change of plans, and instead of a casual formal, I decided to have a costume. Party! My mother's side is crazy for Halloween, so they were immediately on board. I told my father via text and asked him to relay the message to Heather and her mother, knowing full well that he would forget or leave it to the last minute. Saturday comes along and guests start showing up. Most of them are in costumes and some didn't have time to get one. We just provided them with fun hats and cheap wigs. My fiance was dressed as bubbles and I was dressed as

They gave my college fund to her boyfriend, so I gave her retirement to the IRS. My mother's boyfriend's always came with a price tag I had to pay. When I was 10, she emptied my savings to bail out her boyfriend, Rick. When I was 13, she sold my computer to buy her boyfriend Louise a birthday present. When I was 15, she used my college fund contributions from Dad's family to pay her boyfriend James's court fees. Each time she said the same thing, you're too young to understand love. Everything changed when I turned 17 and Keith appeared six months after James went to prison. Unlike the others, Keith didn't pretend to work. He moved in after two weeks, immediately pitching business ideas while spending days playing video games as mom worked 12 hour shifts cleaning houses for cash. When grandma died, she left me $40,000 for college and a trust mom controlled until I turned 18. Mom's eyes lit up at the reading. Keith suddenly had weekly business plans, meeting small investments. Mom called me selfish for not supporting Keith's dreams, insisting family helps family. She accused me of not understanding love and sacrifice. Called her, calling the bank about early withdrawal penalties. When confronted, she claimed she was just gathering information for my future. But something felt wrong. Two weeks before my 18th birthday, I called the bank myself. The account was empty. All $40,000 gone. That night I confronted mom. She didn't deny it. Didn't apologize, didn't even look guilty. She just shrugged and said, Keith needed it more than you do. You can get loans, my grandmother's gift, my future, my trust, all sacrificed for a man who couldn't even get off our couch. Mom had chosen Keith over her own child's education. She kept talking and her words got crueler with each sentence. She said, I would understand when I found real love. She claimed she was teaching me that family makes sacrifices. Then she said the words that changed everything. Given you everything for 18 years, you owe me this. That sentence shattered whatever love I still felt for her. Keith walked in wearing a new gold chain and designer shoes. He smirked and put his arm around mom like he won a prize. That night, I heard them through the wall planning a cruise. They laughed about my reaction to the stolen money. Keith called me a spoiled brat and mom agreed. She said, I've been selfish since birth. I lay there realizing she would never choose me over any man. I remembered her years of tax fraud and her pride in cheating the system. That's when I knew exactly how to destroy her. I spent three months documenting Mom's cash business. I knew all her clients from years of her stories. I wrote down names, addresses and rates. She made at least $50,000 yearly. I found her income notebook and photographed every page. I researched IRS whistleblower programs and Confirmed family members were eligible the reward or could be 30% of collected taxes. I gathered her social media posts bragging about vacations and shopping sprees. I documented Keith's new lifestyle and match the dates to my stolen college fund. By the end, I had enough evidence to bury her in debt forever. I filed the IRS report online with all my evidence showing six years of unreported income totaling $300,000. I included the stolen college fund as additional unreported income. I attached every photograph, every social media screenshot, every documented pattern of Keith's spending. The IRS moved faster than expected because my documentation was thorough and organized. Six weeks later, the audit notice arrived during Keith's birthday party. Mom had invited all their friends to celebrate at her house. She opened the official envelope while everyone watched, probably expecting a birthday card. Her face went from confused to white as she read the letter twice. Her hands started shaking. She excused herself.

Hold it. Moment where you knew you would win. I hated group projects more than anything in college. Every single time I'd end up doing all the work while everyone else just showed up for the grade. So when Professor Williams assigned our final ethics project worth 30% of our grade, I swore things would be different this time. The professor randomly put me with three students I barely knew, Alex, Jordan and Sam. I was actually excited because maybe working with strangers would mean they'd actually care about their grades. Boy, was I wrong. I made a group chat the same day and sent detailed messages about meeting times, dividing up the work and setting deadlines. Radio silence. I tried again the next day. Nothing. I even walked up to Alex after class and asked if he got my messages. He just shrugged and said, yeah, we'll figure it out later. Two weeks passed, a 20 page research paper was due in 10 days and nobody had written a single word. I kept sending messages, trying to set up meetings, offering to do video calls. They left me unread every single time. I had a choice. I could let our whole group fail or I could do what I always did. So I spent the next week pulling all nighters, researching corporate ethics scandals, writing analysis after analysis, adding proper citations and references, 23 pages of solid work. I was exhausted but proud. When I submitted it online, I Only put my name on it, not theirs, just mine. The very next morning, the day before our presentation, my phone started buzzing like crazy. Alex was calling me over and over. When I finally picked up, he sounded panicked. Hey, Maya, we're all ready to present now. Just make sure you add our names back to the title slide before class. Okay? I couldn't believe what I was hearing. Add your names back. You guys didn't help write anything. Come on, don't be like that. We're a team. Just put us on there. I hung up. 20 minutes later, Sam was knocking on my dorm room door, acting all friendly like we were best friends. Maya, hey, we just wanna make sure everything's good for tomorrow. We can all present different sections. What sections did you write? I asked. Well, we didn't technically write them, but we can present them. That's basically the same thing, right? I told her no and close the door. That's when things got ugly. They emailed Professor Williams that same night, claiming I had excluded them maliciously from the project and refused to collaborate. They said I was trying to take all the credit for work they had done. They even said I deleted their contributions from the shared document. Professor Williams replied to all of us the next morning. He said there would be a hearing after class where each person would be graded individually based on what they could prove they contributed. When I walked into the classroom for our presentation, my three group members were already there with printed papers and fake concerned expressions. They had actually printed out what looks like rough drafts with their names on them. During the hearing, they went first. Alex claimed he had written the entire introduction and that I had deleted it and rewritten it in my own words. Jordan said he had researched all the case studies, but I had stolen his work. Sam said she had done the conclusion, but I had cut her out completely. They showed Professor Williams.

Prince, how did the system fail your child? The school called me during a client meeting. Your daughter won't stop crying. We need you here now. My stomach dropped. Maya never cried at school. She was my tough girl who scraped her knee last month and asked for a Spider Man Band Aid while blood ran down her leg. I left my presentation half finished and drove like the world was ending. The secretary's face was pale when I walked in. She pointed down the hall without speaking. That scared me more than the phone call. Maya sat curled in the corner of the nurse's office, arms wrapped around her knees. Her favorite purple dress was torn at the shoulder. The butterfly hair clips I'd put in that morning were gone. When I touched her arm, she jerked away like I was made of electricity. Baby, what happened? I whispered. She wouldn't look at me, just kept staring at the wall with empty eyes. The nurse shifted uncomfortably and told me Maya hadn't said a word since PE class ended. Missus Johnson brought her in like this. I took Maya home. She sat in the back seat, not her usual spot next to me. That night she wouldn't eat her favorite Mac and cheese, wouldn't watch cartoons, just sat on her bed holding her stuffed elephant while helping her into pajamas. I saw them finger shaped bruises on her upper arms, dark purple marks where someone had grabbed her hard My hands shook. Maya, who did this? She finally looked at me. Her voice came out so small. Mister Garcia said, if I tell, he'll hurt you. He said, nobody believes little girls anyway. Mister Garcia, the PE teacher parents loved because he coached the winning soccer team, the one who high fived kids in the hallway, who'd been teaching for 15 years. I called 9 1 1 that night. The female officer who interviewed Maya was gentle, patient. Maya told her everything, how Mister Garcia took her to the equipment room during class, how he made her play a secret game, how it hurt, how he did it to other girls, too, during their special practice time. The principal called me at 6:00am not to apologize, to scold me. He said I should have come to him first, that calling police was premature, that Mr Garcia was a valued member of their community. I recorded the entire call.

How did your daughter find proof your husband was cheating? Okay, listen. My nine year old daughter Chloe is cute, but don't let the dimples fool you. Chloe is pure chaos in a Disney Channel body. She's funny, sneaky, and I swear she came out the womb with Wi Fi because she knows everything. It started on a Saturday morning. She asked for my iPad. Totally normal. Usually she just watches slime videos or those weird kids prank their parents TikToks. Ten minutes later, she storms into the kitchen yelling, Mom, Daddy's cheating on you! With Pop Tart crumbs flying out her mouth. I almost dropped the pancake pan. I'm like, excuse me. She flips the iPad around like it's evidence in a trial and goes, look, he's calling Miss Candy Babe. And yep, there it was. Text synced from his phone. Hearts, kissy emojis, even a sweaty gym selfie. I tried to stay calm, but she's staring at me like Judge Judy in pajamas. So are be divorcing him today or tomorrow? That night, I checked the iPad myself. Messages, pictures, everything. Dude was out here playing secret boyfriend while snoring next to me like a broken lawn mower. I didn't sleep, just sat. They're thinking my nine year old solved my marriage before coffee. Next morning, we're all at breakfast. He's buttering toast like nothing's wrong. My daughter looks him dead in the eye and goes, so how's your girlfriend? This man choked so hard on his bread. I thought I'd have to call 9 1 1. He stutters. What? Who? What girlfriend? She leans forward real serious and says, the one with cheesecake. The one prettier than mom. Then she bites her cereal like she just dropped a diss track. His face went ghost white. He looks at me for backup, and I just sip my coffee like it's a front row ticket to his funeral. He tries to change the subject, but my daughter doesn't stop. You know, mom deserves better. Should we fire him or demote him to maid? This man snapped, you shouldn't be in adult business. And she goes, then stop texting Miss Candy on the family icloud, dummy. I almost spit coffee all over the table. She said it with that little evil grin, like she'd been waiting her whole life for this. After he stormed off, I sat her down. I'm like, sweetie, you can't just explode people's lives like that. And she goes, why not? He exploded yours first. I had no comeback. She was right. My nine year old was smarter than me. Couple days later, I finally confronted him. He did the whole guilty husband monologue. It was just texting. It didn't mean anything. You're overreacting. And I just pulled out the screenshots my daughter saved. Yes, saved. She made a whole photo album labelled dad the liar. She even added little captions like Cotton 4K at eight thirty two PM. This child is an FBI agent in Light up sneakers. He started packing that night. Suitcase wide open, socks flying everywhere. My daughter sat on the couch, swinging her legs, eating Doritos, and shouted, Bye, Felicia! I almost died laughing. He glared at her, but what was he gonna do? Ground her for exposing him? Please. And here's the thing. My daughter didn't even stop there. Two days later, when he came by to talk, she opened the door, looked him up and down, and yelled, mom! The trash took itself out. Slammed the door right in his face. I had to go hide in the bathroom because I was laughing so hard, I couldn't breathe. So, yeah, my life flipped upside down. But my daughter turned into my partner in crime. She's wild, she's loud, and she's the reason I didn't stay with a liar. A week later, Miss Candy texted me, sorry, didn't know he was married. And before I could even reply, Chloe grabbed my phone and wrote back, it's okay, girl. We divorced him. You want custody every other weekend. I swear, I screamed.

My mom checked our location 14 times a day until it destroyed our family. Mom's eating breakfast, scrolling through Facebook while Dad's counting out quarters for gas money when she announces we're all downloading Life 3, 60. We're two months behind on the electrical, but her friend says this app is the only way to keep family safe and honest. I'm 17 and work part time at target while my dad does construction. We don't have time to be anything but safe and honest, she says. If we have nothing to hide, we have nothing to fear, which sounds like something a dictator would say. But whatever. She makes us install it right there at the table and checks that everyone's location is on. And I realize immediately what she doesn't understand about this app. Life 3, 60 doesn't just show where you are. It shows your speed when driving, your phone battery, and sends notifications for everything, including when someone checks someone else's location. Mom works from home doing medical billing and has nothing but time to watch that app all day. Well, dad and I are actually out in the world. Perfect. Now I'll know everyone's safe, she says. But what she means is now she can watch us like the musical jolly chimp from Toy Story. Her phone buzzes and she glances at it. Oh, shoot, I have a doctor's appointment in an hour. Dad offers to drive her, but she says, no, she needs the car. All day for errands. After months ago, my mom asked me to start covering for her when she goes out saying she's shopping or at the doctor's. Whenever dad asks where she is, men lose interest when you mention women. Things she tell me she doesn't realize she just set herself up. Day one and my phone buzzes every 10 minutes with mom checked your location. While I'm at school, dad text me she checked me 14 times this morning and we both realise she's literally sitting there refreshing the app constantly instead of working. Day three, mom calls me screaming because the app says I was going 67 in a 65 and threatens to take my keys. So I start driving under the speed limit, which means I'm late to work and my manager writes me up. Dad gets stuck in traffic, won't go even 1 mile per hour over because mom will see shows up 30 minutes late to his job site and loses a client worth $2,000. Week 2, she sees I stopped at McDonald's for 3 minutes and lectures me about wasting money, which is rich considering she was at the grocery store for 4 hours yesterday and came back with just milk saying nothing good on sale. Dad checks the app and asks her four hours at one store? And mom glares at me like I should have warned her he was checking but how?

I remember how we used to act when our mom didn't come home on time. Like, I swear she said she'd be home at six PM, and the second it hits 6:01, my brain is already writing her obituary. I would think that she died or something. Like, I'd already be imagining a life 20 years down, the life without a mother. I'm pacing around the house like a detective in a Netflix crime DOC. I'm checking the driveway every 10 seconds like I'm waiting on a pizza delivery, looking out the blinds like I'm in a hostage situation. And then when it hits seven, that's when the full panic sets in. I'm googling what to do when your mom is missing, but you're only 11 years old. I was seconds away from calling 9 1 1, like, hi, yes, my mom went to Walgreens and hasn't returned. It's been one hour. I think she got abducted. And it was always the most dramatic thoughts, too. I'd be like, okay, what if she crashed? What if I'm an orphan now? Who's gonna cook dinner? Who's gonna sign my field trip form? Am I gonna be one of those kids on the morning announcements they ask you to pray for? Then she finally walks through the door like, oh, sorry, I saw Aunt Lisa at the store, and we started talking. Girl, I was planning your funeral. I already picked the music. You can't just casually hit me with I ran Into someone. Follow. If you've ever mentally adopted yourself over your mom being 30 minutes late.

Sister in law snooped and stole our baby's name, then announced it right after she gave birth. But her face immediately dropped when she realised that we tricked her. My sister in law Maya has always been competitive with me, since the day I married her brother Jake. She couldn't handle that someone else was getting attention and what she considered her family. When Jake and I got engaged, tried to announce her own engagement at our party. When we bought our first house, she suddenly started house hunting, too. So when we both ended up pregnant at the same time, I knew the competition was about to get intense. Maya was due just two weeks before me, and from the moment we announced, she became absolutely obsessed with finding out our baby name choice. At first it started innocently enough. She'd casually ask during family dinners, have you guys thought about names yet? When we'd de flesh, she'd push harder. Come on, just give me a hint. Then it escalated. Maya started showing up at our house unannounced, trying to peek at any baby books we had lying around. She'd walk through our nursery and comment on everything, clearly fishing for clues. She even asked my mother in law to pressure us into sharing our choice. The breaking point came when I caught her literally going through our mail. When she thought we weren't looking. She was flipping through baby magazines and packages, desperately searching for any evidence of Our name decision. My husband thought I was being paranoid when I told him I suspected Maya wanted to steal our name and use it first. She wouldn't do that, he said, but I knew better. This was exactly the kind of petty move Maya would pull. That's when I decided to set a trap. I created bacon interest boards filled with names I'd never actually consider using. I strategically left a notebook open on our kitchen counter with final decision written in big letters next to the name Aurora Rose. When Maya I came over for dinner, I even coordinated with my mom to call me while Maya was within earshot, having a completely fake conversation about how Aurora fits so perfectly with your family naming tradition. And I'm so excited you finally decided. Maya took the bait completely. Over the next few weeks, she started casually bringing up the name Aurora in random conversations, testing how we'd react. Aurora is such a beautiful name, don't you think? She'd say. Watching our faces carefully, I played along perfectly, acting slightly uncomfortable whenever she mentioned it, like she'd stumbled onto our secret. Two weeks later, Maya went into labor. Within an hour of giving birth, she posted on Facebook, welcome to the world, baby Aurora Rose. Our little princess has finally arrived! The whole family flooded the comments with congratulations, but I noticed Maya kept checking to see if I'd responded. She was clearly waiting for my reaction to her Surprise! The next day at the hospital, Maya was practically glowing with smugness when I walked

Last week I took my grandchildren to a restaurant. My eight year old grandson asked if he could say Grace. As we bowed our heads, he said, god is good, god is great. Thank you for the food, and I would thank you even more if Grandpa gets us ice cream for dessert. And liberty and justice for all. Amen. Along with the laughter from the other customers nearby, I heard a woman remark, that's what's wrong with parenting these days. Kids today don't even know how to pray. Asking god for ice cream, why I never? Hearing this, my grandson burst into tears and asked me, did I do it wrong? Is god mad at me? So, after I assured him that he had done a terrific job and that god was certainly not mad at him, an elderly gentleman approached the table. He winked at my grandson and said, I happen to know that god thought that was a great prayer. Really? My grandson asked, cross my heart, the man replied. Then in a theatrical whisper, he added, indicating the woman whose remark had started this whole thing, too bad she never asks god for ice cream. A little ice cream is sometimes good for the soul. Naturally, I bought my grandchildren ice cream. At the end of the meal, my grandson stared at his ice cream for a moment, and then he did something I will remember the rest of my life. He picked up his sundae. And without a word walked over and placed it in front of the woman. With a big smile he told her here, this is for you. Shove it up your ass, you grouchy old bitch

My teacher thought I was cheating on a test, so she sent me to the E R. When I was in 9th grade, I got stuck with our school's worst teacher who was infamous for trying to make a Muslim girl take off her headwear to prove she wasn't wearing headphones in class. There were a lot of students who got away with cheating by wearing headphones during tests, so she was constantly checking. Since then, she didn't do anything too bad until we had to take our final exam at the end of the year and she stood up to walk around the room. It was really hot that day, so I wore a lighter shirt. I also happen to have type 1 diabetes. You could see my insulin pump that day. My blood sugar was low, so I turned my pump on and walked into class. We were almost done taking the test and she stood up to walk around the room. I was honestly focused on just passing until I heard her walk straight up behind me. In that moment, two things happened. She grabbed my paper off my desk and told me I failed. And I felt her grab the pump on my waist. I just sat there in shock as she walked away and had no idea what had just happened. However, it wasn't until I noticed she was holding Scissors that it clicked what she had just done. She had in the wire hanging Off my waist and assumed I had headphones in. When I looked down, the tube was cut. After a few seconds, my pump started beeping very loudly and everyone started looking at me. A few people sitting around me saw what happened and were in shock. She came over and when she realized what she did, I watched her face turn pale. She had messed up big time and had no idea what to do and neither did I. She told me to go to the nurse and on the way there, I started getting, see, I made it there. I could feel myself starting to pass out. The nurse called 9, 1 1 and I had to go to the hospital. But since that day, I actually started wearing headphones in class because none of the teachers would try anything.

Things I want to know, but I'm afraid to ask. Do I make you happy? Or are you just pretending to accept me the way I am? Do you really mean everything you say to me? Am I ever a part of your plan in life? Or am I just a passenger? Would losing me hurt you? If you need help, do you count me as someone you can turn to? These questions have been lingering in the corners of my mind, and though they may be difficult to voice, they stem from a place of genuine curiosity and vulnerability in the depths of my heart. I cherish our connection, and I wanna understand the depth of your feelings, too. I hope that we can have an open and honest conversation free from judgment or fear, because I believe that true intimacy is born from sharing our innermost thoughts. I value what we have and wanted to grow stronger with each passing day. Built on a foundation of trust and authenticity. You mean the world to me, and knowing the answers to these questions would provide me with the reassurance and clarity I seek. It's not about doubting your love or commitment, but rather about nurturing our bond and ensuring that we are both on the same page. Together, we can navigate any uncertainties and emerge even closer with a love that is unbreakable.
NA

My husband kept forgetting my birthday, so this year I forgot him. For three years straight. Danny would act surprised when my birthday rolled around. First year he said work was crazy and he'd make it up to me. Second year he claimed his phone died so he lost track of dates. Last year he literally asked me why I seemed upset on February 15th. He had no clue it was the day after my birthday. Meanwhile, this guy remembered every sports stat from 1995 and could tell you exactly when his favorite show aired. Each week he had phone reminders for oil changes, dentist appointments, even when to water his plants. But somehow my birthday was this impossible thing to keep track of. My friends kept telling me to just remind him or send hints, but that felt pathetic. If someone cares about you, they remember what matters to you without being nagged about it. This year I decided to test something two weeks before my birthday. I started dropping hints everywhere. I left my birth certificate on the kitchen counter. I circled February 14th on the calendar with a big red heart. I even mentioned it during dinner. My birthday is coming up soon, I said while we ate tacos. He just nodded and kept scrolling his phone. The week before I got more obvious. I showed him a dress online and said this would be perfect for my birthday dinner next week. He mumbled something about it being nice And went back to watching TV. Three days before, I literally said, so what are we doing for my birthday Thursday? He looked confused and asked, what's Thursday? When I told him it was my birthday, he slapped his forehead like he always did and said, right, yeah. I've been so busy with work stuff. Thursday morning came. I woke up expecting something. Anything. Maybe flowers by my bedside or breakfast in bed. Nothing. He got dressed, kissed my cheek, and said he'd be back late because of a client dinner. Not even a happy birthday. I sat there in my pajamas until noon, feeling stupid for hoping things would be different this year. Then I remembered something. His birthday was exactly one month later, March 14th. And for the past four years, I'd thrown him surprise parties, bought expensive gifts, took days off work to plan special celebrations. That's when I made my decision.

Doctors, what patient made you go, how are you even alive? I had an eight year old diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. Without insulin, she'd be dead in six months. I called the mother in to explain the situation. When I, I told her, she was totally relaxed. Oh, I know about the diabetes. The other doctor mentioned it last week. We're handling it naturally, though. No insulin needed. I thought I misheard her. Your daughter needs insulin to live. Her pancreas doesn't work anymore. She will die without it. The mother smiled. We're doing carrot juice therapy instead, 60 ounces a day. Diabetes is just toxin build up in the pancreas. The juice flushes it out. She said it like she was explaining a recipe. I tried showing her the test results. Her blood sugar is 680. She could slip into a coma any moment. The mother stood up and helped her daughter to her feet. Well, thanks for your opinion, but we're good. The carrot cleanse takes three weeks to work fully. We're only on week two. I blocked the door. You can't leave. She's in diabetic ketoacidosis. She needs emergency treatment. The mother laughed. This is why people don't trust doctors. You create fake emergencies. Move or I'm calling security on you. She pushed past me with her barely conscious daughter. After she left, I immediately called my supervisor and hospital legal. We needed an emergency ethics meeting. A child was going to die within an hour. We had social services, the chief of pediatrics and legal on a conference call. The mother had been flagged at three other hospitals. Each time she left when doctors mentioned insulin. I explained the situation. She's giving her type 1 diabetic daughter only carrot juice. The kids in active ketoacidosis. She'll be dead in weeks, maybe days. Legal said without immediate danger, we couldn't force treatment. The chief suggested we call the mother for a formal care meeting, make it sound routine. When I called, she was surprisingly cheerful. Oh, a second opinion? Sure. I love educating doctors about natural healing. She came back that afternoon with a rolling suitcase. Inside were printed Facebook posts, blog articles and a Powerpoint on her laptop she set up like she was giving a business presentation. Let me show you how Big Pharma created the die diabetes lie. She actually had slides. Slide 1, Insulin is made from GMO bacteria. Slide 2, diabetes didn't exist before 1920. Slide 3, every culture has a vegetable that cures diabetes. Chief of pediatrics interrupted. Ma'am, your daughter's blood sugar was 680. She's dying. The mother clicked to her next slide. That's exactly what they want you to think. Look at this graph I made. Couple days later, the school called 9, 1 1. The daughter had collapsed in the cafeteria, completely unresponsive. When they arrived, I recognized her immediately. The orange tinted skin was unmistakable. Blood sugar was 1,100. She was in a diabetic coma. The Mother rushed in 20 minutes later carrying her suitcase of documents. She fainted because they gave her school lunch instead of her juice. That processed food is poison. The kids started seizing right there on the gurney. Foam.

My little sister has had a crush on my husband, but she never expected to get humiliated in such a way. My younger sister, Ariana turned into a homewrecker the moment my husband Kevin, slipped the ring on my finger and started a desperate pick me routine. If Kevin were blue, she'd show up in blue. If you mentioned liking something, she'd become an expert overnight. If you posted about a restaurant, she coincidentally appeared during our date. It started subtle, almost innocent, even like sitting next to Kevin at every family dinner, Ariana would squeeze between us, claiming she couldn't hear from the other end. I didn't mind since family is family. But after six months, it got obvious. Kevin joined a gym near his office. Ariana got a membership there the next day, showing up during his workout times in tiny sports bras. Kevin mentioned liking astronomy once. Suddenly, Ariana was texting him NASA articles daily, asking, can you explain this to me? Then came the fake emergencies. Her car broke down near Kevin's office. Her apartment had a gas leak when I was out of town. She needed help moving heavy boxes that turned out to be empty, Kevin always told me, immediately showing me her texts with eye rolls. She's just young and confused, he'd say. And I agreed until she officially went too far. A hard knock at 9:00am and there stood Ariana in a tiny white sundress, full makeup, hair curled like a magazine. Shoot, I need Kevin's help moving furniture, she announced, pushing past me. Where is he? But we both knew she lived in a furnished apartment. I was about to tell her to leave when she added, I'm sure you have errands to run. You can go away now. She was literally trying to dismiss me from my own home. Kevin came downstairs and she immediately grabbed his arm. Oh, perfect. You're already dressed. I promise I'll return him in one piece. She actually winked at me. I felt my chest burn with rage, but then had a different thought. I headed upstairs, loudly saying, I need to take a bath. But I didn't leave or go to the bathroom. I stayed upstairs where I could hear everything through the vents. Didn't waste any time. Oh, my God, Kevin, you're so muscular, she giggled, clearly touching his arm. Do you work out every day? I bet you could lift me with one hand. Wanna try? I rolled my eyes. This girl had zero shame. I kept folding laundry, waiting for Kevin's polite deflection. Instead, I heard him say, seriously, Ariana, can I tell you something important? My heart sank. Oh, god, here we.

Friend said I share too much about my feelings, so I stopped sharing anything at all. Jess came over to my place Friday night and I could tell something was bothering her by the way she kept sighing. You know what Britney told me today? She said, flopping down on my couch. Her boyfriend is so mysterious and she's obsessed with him. Meanwhile, you texted me 12 times about being nervous for your presentation. The way she said it made me feel like I was some kind of burden. I wish you were more mysterious, more of a challenge. Should have known this would end badly when three weeks later she'd be crying at my door. But that night, I just felt hurt and said, fine, I'll be mysterious that night. I usually would have texted her good night, but I didn't and it felt wrong not doing it. She sent me three question marks right away and I just wrote back, all good and left it at that. Saturday morning came and normally I'd text her about my coffee and ask what she was up to, but I kept my phone in my pocket. Noon she was texting you okay and I just sent a thumbs up, which killed me because I actually wanted to talk to her. Monday was the worst because I got the promotion I've been working for and all I wanted was to call her and celebrate. When we went to dinner that night, she Asked about my day and I just said same old while scrolling through my phone, even though inside I was bursting to tell her. She leaned across the table trying to figure out what was going on with me. You seem different, she said. Good, different. And the crazy part was she seemed more into me than she had in months, which made me feel powerful but also completely hollow inside. The second week, she started showing up at my place without calling first and cooking these fancy dinners, basically doing anything to crack me open. I can't figure you out anymore, she said. Wednesday night and she sounded excited about it. Britney so jealous, she says. I got the mysterious boyfriend Jackpot. I wanted to tell her how dumb this whole thing was and how much I missed just talking to her normally, but I just shrugged and kept watching TV. my dad called because my mom was in the hospital for minor surgery and he was freaking out. I spent three hours calming him down while Jess sat next to me trying to figure out what was happening. After I hung up, she asked, is everything okay? And I wanted to fall into her arms and tell her everything, family, stuff. I said instead, it's handle. She kissed me harder than she had in months and whispered, you're so strong. But I wasn't strong at all. I was just pretending. The third, Thursday night at eleven PM Jess showed up at my door with her makeup running down her face, shaking.

You do if your best friend confessed to deleting someone. My best friend Mike called me at 3:00am last Tuesday, voice shaking. I need to tell you something and I need you to listen. Without hanging up. We've been friends since middle school, so I knew something was seriously wrong. Remember that guy, Derek, who kept harassing my sister at work, the one who followed her home and kept showing up at her apartment? I remembered Derek was this creepy older guy who wouldn't take no for an answer. Mike's sister, Emma, had filed multiple complaints, but nothing stuck. Well, he's not going to bother anyone anymore, Mike said quietly. My blood went cold. What do you mean he's not going to bother anyone? There was this long pause where I could hear Mike breathing heavily through the phone. I was driving home from Emma's place last night around midnight. She'd been crying because Derek showed up at her work again, this time with flowers and a note saying he knew where she lived. I was so angry I could barely see straight. Mike continued. That's when I saw Derek's car parked outside her apartment complex. He was just sitting there in the dark watching her windows. I pulled over and walked up to his car. When he saw me, he started laughing and said Emma would come around. Eventually, I snapped. I dragged him out of the car and we started fighting in the parking lot. But then he. voice_to_text: School thought they were geniuses when they made the Wi-Fi password impossible to crack. They didn't realize they just declared war on 2,000 bored teenagers with nothing but time and spite. It started when Principal Morrison announced a new policy. Students caught sharing the cool Wi-Fi password will face immediate suspension. The password was 47 characters long, randomly generated every week and only given to teachers. My friend Marcus was the first to strike back. He brought a 30 foot Ethernet cable to cool and plugged directly into the computer lab wall. When Mr Morrison walked by, Marcus was sitting in the hallway, laptop connected, cable sneaking under the door. Marcus, what are you doing using wired internet, sir? The policy only mentions Wi-Fi. That cable is a tripping hazard. I put up caution sign. Marcus had indeed played tiny yellow wet floor signs every three feet along the cable. Mr Morrison updated the policy. No Ethernet cables over 6 feet. So Marcus brought six separate six foot cables and five friends. They formed a human chain, each person holding a laptop connected to each other, passing internet from the lab to the cafeteria like a digital bucket brigade. This is ridiculous, Mr Morrison said. This is compliance. Marcus replied, each cable is exactly six feet. New rule, no daisy chaining connection. That's when Jennifer got involved. She noticed the smart TV in the library was connected to Wi-Fi. She screen mirrored her phone to the TV. Then use the TV's browser to create a hotspot broadcast to her laptop. Jennifer, you're using the school Wi-Fi? No, sir, I'm using the TV's connection. The TV isn't a student. The TV doesn't need suspension threats, she added sweetly. Mr Morrison banned using school devices as intermediary. Alex took a different approach. He stood outside the teacher's lounge with a clipboard claiming he was conducting a password security audit for his computer science project. He'd ask teachers to write their password down to test memory pattern. 3 teachers actually did it before word spread. Alex, this is deception. This is social engineering research, sir. Very educational. Did you get the password? That would be unethical to reveal. Meanwhile, Sarah had noticed something beautiful. The attendance system auto connected to Wi-Fi when teachers logged in. She volunteered as an office aide and memorized the password as it briefly appeared on screen during setup. She didn't share it though. Instead, she sold a service. Bring her device, she'd connect it for you, then change your Mac address so it looked like a printer. By week 3, half the school was showing up as HP Laserjet on the network. Why do we have 400 printer? Mr Morrison asked it. Those aren't printers it, he replied. Then what are they? Creative student. The arms race escalated. Ryan figured out the password was always posted in the teacher's bathroom. Thinking students wouldn't see it there, he used a drone with a camera. During lunch when the bathroom Was empty. The footage was shaky but readable. Ryan, you flew a drone into school property, into the courtyard. Sir, the bathroom window was open. I was investigating ventilation efficiency for my environmental science project. Mr Morrison put curtains on the bathroom window. But the masterpiece came from quiet Emily. She noticed the school's old Wi-Fi routers were still broadcasting, just hidden from the network list. They'd forgotten to change those passwords. Those unpaid child support checks, mom and Garrett had been collecting them for years. Pierce was nothing like the deadbeat mom had described. He was kind, successful and genuinely interested in my life. He'd saved every penny of child support in a college fund, enough to cover four years at any university I chose. Father's Day arrived and Garrett expected his usual Celebration. Colton had made him a clay mug.

Why the fuck are English teachers such a hit or miss? She will either be the friendliest, most lovely and understanding person in the world or the strictest bitch. The one will arrive 10 minutes late into the class, start complaining about the weather, traffic, the principal or even her husband then delay the lesson with a 20 minute existential conversation, let you eat, drink and chew gum and you might even watch a movie at the end of the hour while the other will stand as a North Korean solidator in the middle of the room and begin threatening students with pop quizzes and detention. Your friend then makes a joke about her. You better have military grade training cause even the smallest chuckle will trigger a nuclear chain reaction. You're then struggling to not laugh by keeping your mouth shut or even pretending you're choking. He then expects you to share what was so funny with the class and you're sitting there in awkward silence pretending you've learnt your lesson to avoid further trouble. And don't even get me started on the curse of the parallel class. You are stuck in a room with the bitch screaming on the top of her lungs, assigning a ton of homework and even denying you to go to the fucking toilet while the other class would be singing, watching movies and making pancakes with the sweetheart. No.

Told my parents I won't change my name. Because of their regret, I legally changed my name to Atlas when I turned 18. My birth certificate had Michael William Reynolds, Jr. On it, named after my father, who walked out when I was two. For 16 years, I hated being called junior or Little Mike. Every time someone said my name, it felt like dragging around the shadow of a man who decided we weren't worth keeping. School always started the same. Michael Reynolds, the teacher would call. I go by MJ. I'd answer, trying to create distance. Mom worked two jobs after he left. She'd help with homework despite being exhausted, and never complained. Not even when grandparents would say, he looks more like his father every day. As if that was a compliment. When I was 15, mom started dating David. He was nothing like my father. Quiet, reliable, with a dry sense of humor. An English professor who wore sweater vests and collected maps. His first visit, he brought me a journal instead of forcing some guy bonding activity. David never tried to replace my dad. He just showed up. He came to baseball games with his grading work, occasionally looking up to cheer. He helped with college applications and never made me feel like a burden. Once I heard him tell mom, he's not my son, but I couldn't be prouder if he was. Before senior year, I researched name changes. Nothing felt right. Until I Remembered a book David gave me about Greek mythology. Atlas, the Titan who held up the heavens. That resonated when I told them my plan. Mom was supportive, but confused. Why Atlas? She. He asked. Because Atlas carried the world on his shoulders. That's how I felt, carrying Dad's name when he couldn't carry his responsibilities. At least Atlas never put down his burden and walked away. David nodded. Names have power. They tell a story. Exactly. I want to tell my own. After my birthday, I filed the paperwork. Six weeks later, I became Atlas Reynolds. My first college letter, addressed to my new name, is still pinned to my board. Everything was fine until last week, when my biological father called. Mom handed me the phone with a strange look. Junior. How's my little Michael? Junior? My stomach dropped. That person doesn't exist anymore. What? My name is Atlas now. He laughed like it was a joke. That's not your name. You're Michael William Reynolds, junior. Named you myself right before you left. Added, I legally changed it. He said he was changed. Sorry. Wanted to reconnect. He'd moved back to town with his new family, but wanted to make things right with his first son. He kept repeating my old name, like he could force it back onto me. Yesterday, I found his car in our driveway. Mom and David sat stiffly in the living room with my biological father on our couch. Like he belonged there. They ambushed me with dinner. Mom kept giving apologetic glances. David was quiet. My father dominated with stories about his new life, kids and business. At dessert, he addressed the elephant in the room. So you've changed your name to Atlas. Like the MacBook? Like the Titan, I corrected. Well, he chuckled. Time to read.

Do you guys ever wonder if you even matter? Because like I feel so unimportant in other people's lives. I don't feel loved, liked or even wanted around. Everyone I know can go days without talking to me or even noticing I'm gone. I feel like I'm easily replaceable and there's nothing I can do about that. I'll never be anyone's first choice, let alone second or third. In fact, does everyone see me as a burden? Nothing but an annoyance to talk to? And no, I won't tell anyone privately about this because what if someone starts talking to me out of pity because they feel obligated to? In fact, just telling you all this makes me feel like I'm begging for attention. I just wanna feel appreciated. Like my presence is enjoyed by someone. Like someone will notice when I'm gone. Someone will reach out to me when I seem quieter than usual. Someone will care about me even when I feel unlovable. Just someone, please. Anyways, bye. This is trend hopper 1:01. Signing out. I hope no one else feels this way about themselves.

What made the high school legend become a legend? Our chemistry teacher, Mr. Rodriguez, had this insane rule. If your phone made any sound during class, he'd lock it in his desk for a full week. Not the day, the entire week. Senior year, everyone knew someone who'd lost their phone to him. He kept them like trophies in his desk drawer, grinning whenever kids begged to get them back. There was this quiet kid, Marcus, who worked nights at McDonald's to help his mom pay bills. Twelve year old sister Lily walked home from Jefferson Middle every day through this sketchy area near the auto shops on Fifth Street. She was supposed to text Marcus the second she got home. One Tuesday, during our midterm, Marcus's phone buzzed just once. Text. Rodriguez didn't even look up from his crossword puzzle. Just held out his fat hand. Phone. See you next Tuesday, Mr. Johnson. Marcus went pale. Please, Mr. Rodriguez, my sister should have put it on silent. Your poor planning isn't my emergency. Marcus actually got on his knees, begged. Explained about his mom's double shifts at the hospital, about Lily being alone, about the creeps who hung around that neighborhood. Rodriguez just smiled and slid the phone into his desk. Maybe you'll think twice next time. That afternoon changed everything. Lily never made it home. Some freak in a white van had been watching Jefferson middle for weeks. When she tried calling Marcus first, like she always did. When Scared his phone. Phone just rang in Rodriguez's locked drawer. She was missing for four hours. Four hours of Marcus pacing the McDonald's parking lot, checking the time, knowing something was wrong, but having no way to know what. Police found her behind the Valvoline on Eighth Street. Physically okay, but she wouldn't stop shaking. Wouldn't talk for three days. Marcus came to school the next morning looking like he'd aged 10 years. He walked straight to Rodriguez's room during lunch. I need my phone back.

The worst nightmare a burglar could ever face. My roommate Lisa was doing her nightly skincare routine when we heard glass breaking downstairs. She just applied a thick green face mask and was wearing her ratty bathrobe with hair and rollers. Did you hear that? I whispered. Lisa grabbed her phone to call 9 1 1, but then got this evil grin. Wait, I have a better idea. She crept to the top of the stairs and let out the most blood curdling scream I've ever heard, then started speaking in tongues. Literally just gibberish that sounded vaguely Latin. Spiritus malum, enter this vessel. I heard the burglar drop something and curse. Lisa crawled down the stairs backwards like the girl from the Exorcist, still screaming in her made up demon language. The green face mask was cracking, making her look legitimately terrifying. The burglar was backing toward the window when our other roommate, Ben, emerged from his room. He immediately caught on. The possession is spreading! He yelled. Everyone get the salt! Ben started throwing table salt everywhere while chanting the Pokemon theme song in a deep, ominous voice. The burglar was now pressed against the wall. RTB forgotten on the floor. Please, he begged. Leave. I'm sorry. Lisa's head snapped toward him. She put in her glow in the dark Halloween contacts. In the dim light, her eyes were literally glowing green. You disturbed the ritual, she growled. That's when our fourth roommate, Kevin, joined in. He emerged Playing his violin badly, just screeching notes while swaying like he was in a trance. The demons need music! Ben shouted, now drawing symbols on the wall with ketchup. Say louder! The burglar tried to run, but Lisa's spider walked toward him at surprising speed. He actually screamed. I need an old priest and a young priest, I yelled, getting into it. I'm Protestant! The burglar cried. I don't know any priests! Lisa stood up suddenly, did a perfect backbend and whispered, then you're screwed! The man literally wet himself. I saw the stain spreading on his jeans. Kevin's violence screeching intensified. Ben was now speaking in Klingon. Lisa started doing that creepy clicking sound from the grudge. The burglar fell to his knees. What do you want from me? Your soul, Lisa hissed. Or your confession? I'll confess. I've robbed 12 houses. I'll tell you everything! He started listing addresses, eightes where he'd sold stuff. Ben was frantically taking notes while still pretending to be possessed. When the cops arrived, they found a burglar in tears, begging for an exorcist. Lisa, still in full green face mask and glowing contacts. Catch up! Demon symbols on our walls. Kevin playing my heart will go on badly on violin. Ben reading the burglar his rights and clanging on. The burglar immediately confessed to everything. Begged the cops to take him to a church instead of jail. Kept asking if we were really human. The officer looked at Lisa. Ma'am, what exactly Happened here. Skincare night, she said sweetly. Very important for your pores. They took the burglar away. He was muttering about the green demon and violin of the damned. Cops came back later for our statements. One of them finally cracked. In 20 years on the force, I've never had a purse bag for holy water in the squad car. Turns out the burglar had been hitting houses in our area for months. His full confession cleared over a dozen cases. The detective said whatever you did probably saved him from years more crime. He found religion real quick. Already signed up for seminary school. Lisa's review of her faith.

What family tradition made you realise your mom wasn't going to grow old? In our family, when a husband dies, the widow has exactly 40 days to follow him into the afterlife. They called it the Eternal Service. Packed because apparently men needed servants even after death. I was seven when I watched my Aunt Ling drink the ceremonial poison at Uncle Ling's 40th Day memorial. Her hands shook as she raised the cup, but her mother in law held her wrist steady, making sure every drop went down. Aunt May was 23. She tried to run on day 38. Made it all the way to the bus station before Uncle Ling's brothers dragged her back. I remember her begging, saying she was pregnant. They said the baby could serve Uncle Ling too. My mom would brush my hair every night and tell me how romantic it was that wives love their husbands so much they couldn't live without them. But I saw the way her hands trembled. Whenever dad got a cold, I saw her counting his grey hairs. Like she was calculating how many years she had left. Sometimes I catch her staring at the kitchen knives. Not an escape every way, but like she was measuring which one would be sharpest in 20 years. The thing about this tradition was it wasn't even that old. My great grandfather started it after his brother's widow remarried someone younger and prettier. He said it was about loyalty, but everyone Knew it was about control. Dead women can't inherit property. Dead women can't remarry. Dead women can't testify about what their husband did to them. Dead women can't tell anyone about the bruises hidden under their funeral clothes. The ceremonies were always the same day. 40 would arrive and the whole family would gather. The widow would wear white, her husband's favorite dress. She'd serve tea to his relatives one last time. Then they'd bring out the cup. Always porcelain, always with painted flowers. The poison smelled like almonds. They'd make her drink it in front of everyone, then lay her next to her husband's photo until she stopped breathing. Usually it took about 20 minutes. The younger kids were supposed to watch to learn about duty. When I was 15, Dad had a heart attack. That he survived, but it changed everything. Mom started acting differently. She'd wake me up at 3:00am for lessons. First, she taught me how to forge signatures, making me practice Dad's name until I could do it perfectly. Then came the banking stuff. How to transfer money without triggering alerts. How to hide assets in different names. She showed me websites for fake IDS. Taught me which states were easiest to disappear in. Made me memorize bus routes to the Mexican border. Just in case you ever need to disappear, she'd say. But we both knew who really needed to disappear. Then she showed me the videos. She'd been collecting them for years. Any Footage of widow ceremonies from old family gatherings. She had them hidden on an encrypted hard drive labelled recipe collection. She'd pause at certain moments. Look at Aunt Ling's cup. See how it's different from Aunt May's, she'd say. Look at Aunt Lou's funeral. Notice how the coffin is so light when they carry it. Look at how her sister keeps checking her phone during the burial. That's when I Learned about the secret network. For 20 years, widows have been faking their deaths. Some use special drugs that slowed their heartbeat to nothing for 48 hours. One aunt was a nurse who'd been stealing them from the hospital for years. Others had doctor friends who falsified death certificates for cash. There was a whole underground railroad of safe houses in other states where dead women started new lives. They had new name, new social security numbers, new everything. Mom taught me the code words at family gatherings. Such a peaceful passing meant the widow escaped successfully. She fought till the end. Meant someone was suspicious. Beautiful ceremony meant they needed help with documents. The flowers were perfect. Meant they needed money. She's with him now. Meant she didn't make it out. I started helping when I was 17. Creating fake
