voice_to_text: The only one who wants kids but doesn't want to actually make one. Like you want me to be pregnant for 9 months? Bro I can barely survive school. Is there a build a baby shop? Cause I also low key want to customize my baby. Like yeah, I want the little curly hair and chubby cheeks combo. Maybe give them my sarcasm and someone else's math skills because I've been failing since birth. I don't wanna do the freaky either. Like why is that step even required? Why do I have to risk my soul insanity in a sweaty emotional situation just to unlock the baby starter pack? The fact people would know I did too. And the way people say but it's all worth it in the end. Like girl, that's what they say after surviving a car crash. You're not convincing me to grow a human like it's a house plant when I literally forget to feed myself some days. I'm not stable enough to be a life factory. why is no one talking about the fact that you don't even get a break after the baby's born? Like now you get to wake up every two hours and get screamed at by a bald roommate with anger issues. I just want the baby. I want to dress them like a minion and send them to preschool with a juice box. But I want to skip the pregnancy part. Skip the pain, skip the loading screen. Give me the kid. Just spawn them in. At this point every time I hear someone say I miss being pregnant, I start glitching. Miss what? The swollen feet? The back pain? Being built like a human recliner with a foot sticking out your ribs? No, cause at that point your body is not yours anymore. I don't even read the instructions on frozen waffles and now I'm supposed to build a whole human from scratch? And don't even get me started on baby names cause I already know I'd name my kid something adorable. And then he'd grow up to be a middle school menace with a mullet and a scooter. Who calls teachers by their first name? I'm not risking all that just to have my custom baby turn out like a Fortnite sweat who screams into a headset and tells other 12 year olds you're trash while I'm in the back crying over how I spent 9 months assembling this child just for him to rage quit over losing in Roblox Obby level 2. And the emotions! I crashed out yesterday because my charger fell behind the bed. Now imagine me pregnant.

voice_to_text: The worst thing your parents made you believe. When I was 12 years old, my mother slit her wrist in front of me because I asked to go to a friend's birthday party. And as she bled into our kitchen sink, she made me promise I'd never try to leave her again. She survived that time, barely. While the paramedics worked on her, she gripped my hand with bloody fingers and whispered, this is what happens when you abandon me. I spent three days in the hospital chapel, 13 years old and convinced. I almost murdered my mother by wanting to go to a sleepover. When she came home, arm bandaged and eyes hollow, she made me sleep in her bed so she could hold on to me all night. I need to know you're here, she said. Otherwise, the darkness comes back. The rules formed quickly after that. I couldn't join clubs because staying late at school feels like you're choosing them over me. I couldn't have friends over because their energy disrupts our bond. Each boundary came with the same threat, sometimes spoken, sometimes just a gesture toward her scarred wrists. He kept razors displayed on the bathroom counter like weapons, reminding me what would happen if I broke her heart again. By 14, I was homeschooled and completely isolated. Mom said it was better this way, just us two against a world that didn't understand our connection. She have good days where she braid my hair and We watch movies and I think maybe this was enough. But then I mention wanting to learn to drive someday and she'd go silent. She lock herself in the bathroom and I sit outside the door begging her to come out. She'd emerge hours later showing me fresh cuts on her thighs. Practice cuts she call them for when you finally abandoned me for real. I attempted my first real escape. At 15, I'd found a youth shelter address at the library and memorized it. One night while mom slept, I packed a bag and made it to the front door. But she was sitting in the dark living room waiting. I felt you pulling away, she said calmly. Then she swallowed an entire bottle of sleeping pills in front of me. I called 9 1 1 and rode with her to the hospital, holding her hand while they pumped her stomach. When she woke up, she smiled sadly. You did this, she said, but at least you stayed to watch. After that, she installed bells on my bedroom door and windows. She test me randomly, pretending to hurt herself to see if I try to leave or just save her. I always chose to save her, but I was dying inside, suffocating under the weight of keeping her alive. I started writing goodbye letters I never send, hiding them in my textbooks. I tried to get away again. When I was six. Mom had fallen asleep after taking anxiety Medication. And I thought I had time. I made it three blocks before a police car pulled up. Mom had called them claiming I was mentally unstable. She'd shown them my hidden letters as evidence. As they drove me home, she texted me, if you'd kept going, you would have found my body when you came back. I had the bath ready that night. She showed me a new scar on her stomach. I did this while you were gone, she said. She made me help her bandage it, narrating how she would have cut deeper if I made it another block. Next time you leave, she promised, I'll make sure I time it perfectly. You'll be free, but you'll be a murderer. I became. I'm hyper vigilant, watching for signs she was spiraling. My entire existence became keeping her from the edge. When I caught her standing on our apartment balcony at 3:00am, I didn't ask why. I just took her hand and let her back to bed. But then I got a scholarship to art school. Mom found the acceptance letter before I could hide it. She didn't say anything, just disappeared into the bathroom. I heard water running and pounded on the door. When she finally.

Wife ignored me at the party until her friend whispered, you're mine tonight. Wife panicked when reality hit. My wife dragged me to her book club's annual holiday party at Monica's house. I hate these things, but she insisted I come for moral support and to be social for once. The second we walked through Monica's front door, decorated with enough Christmas lights to power a small city, my wife spotted her crew and literally walked away mid sentence while I was still taking off my coat. I spent the first 30 minutes standing alone by the elaborate cheese spread, watching her pose for Instagram stories with her girlfriends. They were all dressed like they were hitting downtown clubs instead of discussing romance novels in suburbia. Looks like you're having about as much fun as I am, said a voice behind me. I turned to find Roxanne, my wife's newest friend from the group. Blonde, unconfident, always perfectly put together. The type who somehow makes everyone else feel underdressed just by existing. Oh, you know me, I said, grabbing another cracker. Life of the party. She laughed. Actually laughed. Not the light chuckle people usually give. At least someone here has a sense of humor. I've been listening to 20 minutes of discussion about whether Christian Grey was problematic or misunderstood. We started talking about actual books instead of whatever surface level analysis was happening in the living room. She'd read everything from Murakami to McCarthy. Smart, articulate, and she Actually made eye contact when speaking. Your wife mentioned you're a writer, Roxanne said, leaning against the kitchen counter. I'd love to read something of yours sometime. I bet you have interesting perspectives. My chest tightened. My wife had never asked to read my work, not once in three years of marriage. I'd even want on a small literary contest last month, and she'd said, that's nice, before scrolling back to TikTok. She talks about my writing? I asked. Roxanne's expression shifted slightly. Well, she mentioned it once. Said you're always typing away in your office. She. Actually, now that I think about it, she never really talks about you during our meetings. Like, at all. That hit harder than it should have. I was invisible, even in conversations I wasn't part of. Roxanne must have seen something in my face because she stepped closer. I'm sorry. I shouldn't have said that. No, it's fine, I said, though it wasn't accurate. Probably from across the room, I caught my wife glancing over while pretending to listen to Courtney's story about her divorce lawyer. Her eyes arrowed slightly, seeing Roxanne and me talking. Roxanne noticed, too, and smiled. Well, well. Looks like someone finally remembered you exist. My wife looked away quickly, laughing too loudly at whatever Courtney had said. You know what's fun? Roxanne said, moving even closer. I always wondered what her mysterious husband was like. She acts like she's single half the time. Tonight, I'm right here. I Said surprising myself with the edge in my voice. Roxanne's smile turned predatory. Yes, you are. She glanced toward the living room where my wife was now openly staring at us, her conversation with Courtney completely forgotten. Should we give her something to actually notice? Roxanne whispered and raised her voice just enough for the nearby wives to hear. You know what? Forget about her tonight. You're mine now. The effect was immediate. Conversation stopped. Heads turn. My wife appeared beside us faster than I thought humanly possible. Her face flushed red. What did you just say to my husband? She demanded, her voice carrying across Monica's kitchen. Roxanne shrugged with practiced innocence. Just keeping him company, since you seem so busy with your friends. My wife grabbed my arm like she was claiming territory. We're leaving right now. But you haven't even talked to Monica yet, I said. Now! She hissed, already pulling me toward the door. The car ride home was 15 minutes of arctic silence. Finally, as we pulled into our driveway, she spoke. I can't believe Roxanne would flirt with you like that right in front of everyone. How embarrassing. I turned to look at her. How would you know what happened? You ignored me the entire night. Her mouth opened, then closed. The silence that followed told me everything I needed to know about our marriage.

What happened when the calm guy finally snapped? I worked in logistics at the shipping company for like eight years. Everyone called me the most chill guy there. I never got mad when people messed up my paperwork, never complained when they scheduled me for overtime last minute. Even when the coffee machine broke for two whole weeks and I was getting these awful headaches every afternoon, I just bought my own instant coffee and dealt with it. My supervisor, Todd, would always joke that I was made of chamomile tea or something. Every quarter I got these little certificates saying reliable and professional. I kept them in my desk drawer like some kind of weird trophy collection. Then HR came up with this brilliant new policy. Anonymous internal behaviour feedback. Basically, anyone could report anyone for being difficult or unprofessional. One report got you a warning. Two reports meant you lost your quarterly bonus. 3 reports and you were sitting in HR getting reviewed for termination. I wasn't worried. I mean, what was I gonna get reported for? Being too quiet? I literally helped train half the people on my team. When Ryan started 2 years ago, I taught him how to use the forklift, covered his shifts when his kid got sick, even helped him pass his safety exam by staying late to practice with him. But then I got my first warning email. Just sitting there in my inbox on a Tuesday morning. Like a punch to The gut. You have received an internal behavioral concern. Please review our workplace conduct policies. Stared at that email for, like, 10 minutes. I asked my desk neighbor, Kevin, if he knew what I could have possibly done. He just shrugged and said maybe someone was having a bad day and took it out on me. Two weeks later, another email. Same thing. Second internal behavioral concern received. I went straight to HR, asked Janet what exactly I was being accused of. She smiled that fake customer service smile and said they couldn't reveal specifics to protect the anonymity of the reporting process. She could tell me the general nature of the complaints. Apparently, I was making people uncomfortable with passive aggressive behavior and giving people hostile eye contact. Eye contact? I literally got reported for looking at people. I actually laughed out loud in her office. I asked her if she was serious. She said they take all workplace concerns very seriously and I should reflect on how my behavior might be affecting others. The third report came three days later. You have received three internal behavioral concerns. Please schedule a meeting with HR to discuss your continued employment. I printed out every performance review I'd gotten for the past eight years. All excellent ratings. Wrote this calm, professional response explaining that I had no idea what these reports were about. I even asked Kevin and two other co workers to write statements saying I was always professional and Helpful HR scheduled the meeting for the following Monday. Janet sat there taking notes while I presented my case. She nodded and smiled and said they'd review everything carefully by Friday. The promotion I've been expecting for months went to Ryan instead. That's when something clicked in my brain. I went to Best Buy that week.

What happened when my mom demanded 24 7 access to my phone? When I turned 15, my mom went from strict to straight up paranoid. One night after dinner, she plopped down next to me with this weird smile and said she was installing a family safety app on my phone. I watched her tap away, giving herself access to everything. My location, photos, texts, even my drafts on social media. It's just to keep you safe, honey, she said, handing my phone back like nothing had changed. But everything had changed. It felt like having a stalker who lived in my house. At first I tried to be cool about it. Maybe it would calm her down, right? Wrong. Things got insane fast. She text me in the middle of conversations asking who I was with. She'd comment on memes I hadn't even posted yet because she was reading my drafts. Worst part? She started replying to my friends pretending to be me. My buddy Jake texted asking if I wanted to hang out, and my mom replied, sure thing, buddy! With way too many exclamation points. Jake called me laughing, asking why I was texting like a soccer mom. I had no idea what he meant until I checked my messages. Then came the day that broke me. I was in history class when Mrs. Wilson pulled me aside. She look uncomfortable as hell. Liam, your mother called the school. She's concerned about some message you sent about Me. My stomach dropped. I knew exactly what she meant. I texted my best friend Kyle the night before, joking about how our history teacher's haircut looked like she stuck her finger in an electrical socket. It was just stupid friend stuff, not meant for anyone else. But my mom had read it and called the school to complain about my private joke. I wanted to disappear into the floor. By lunch, Kyle wasn't talking to me. Neither was Jake. Word got around that my mom was reading everything, and suddenly nobody wanted to text me anymore. Some kids even blocked me. It was like my social life had a disease, and the disease was my mom. That night, I stared at my phone, feeling trapped. But then I noticed something. The tracking app worked both ways. It logged every time someone accessed the account. I spent hours studying those logs, and what I found made my skin crawl. My mom wasn't just checking my phone during the day. She was logging in at 1:00am, 2:00am, even 3:00am. She was forwarding my messages to her laptop. She was screenshotting my photos. He was living inside my phone 24 7. So I came up with a plan. I created a fake friend named Daniel, made up this whole persona, gave him a backstory, even found some random photos online to use as his profile pic on a group chat with myself. Then I started a long conversation with Daniel about this Epic party happening at some remote barn outside town. I made it sound exclusive, secretive, like something a paranoid mom would totally freak out about. I mentioned the address random dirt road I found on Google Maps that LED to absolutely nothing. I talked about how it was starting at midnight, how everyone was going to be there, how I couldn't wait to finally do something without my mom knowing. Then I put my phone down and waited. At 1:00am, the app logged that she opened the conversation. At 1:00am, I heard her bedroom Door Creek open. At 1:00am, I heard the garage door at

My wife said don't lecture my kids, get your own. When I tried to correct my stepdaughter, I just smiled and said, alright. I'm Brandon, 38 and married to Samantha for three years. She has twin 12 year olds from her first marriage, Charlotte and Aiden. Their dad sends birthday cards twice a year if we're lucky. Last Tuesday, I caught Charlotte stealing 20 bucks from Samantha's purse. When I confronted her, she rolled her eyes and said, you're not my real dad. You can't tell me what to do. I calmly told Samantha what happened. Instead of addressing the theft, she got defensive. Don't lecture my kids about money. If you want a parent so badly, get your own children. That's dumb. But I just smiled and said, alright. See, what Samantha didn't know was that I've been covering their car insurance, phone bills and school supplies for months. While she struggled with debt, I'd also been quietly setting aside college funds for both kids. Four hundred dollars a month each straight into savings accounts they didn't even know existed. The next morning, I canceled everything. Car insurance, gone. Phone plan, terminated. The college accounts I'd opened, closed and transferred to my personal savings. I also stopped buying groceries. No more weekly 200 dollar trips to keep the pantry stocked. No more paying for their Netflix, Spotify or Charlotte's dance classes that cost me $150 a month. Aiden soccer registration fees, not my problem anymore. I even canceled the Family gym membership and stopped paying for their school lunches. Every subscribe, every monthly payment, every little expense I've been quietly handling, all of it gone. When Charlotte's phone got shut off at school and she couldn't call her friends, she came home furious. Why isn't my phone working? Ask your mom, I said, not looking up from my laptop. Aiden couldn't get picked up from soccer practice because as the car insurance had lapsed and Samantha's registration was expired, she had to leave work early, costing her overtime pay she desperately needed. That evening, Samantha panicked when she opened the fridge to find it nearly empty. The pantry was bare except for some stale crackers and a can of beans. Where's all the food? What happened to everything, she demanded, hands shaking as she looked at the empty shelves. I shrugged. You said, get my own kids so I'm focusing on the children who'll actually be mine someday. These aren't my responsibility anymore. You made that crystal clear. But Brandon, I didn't mean. You absolutely meant it. I interrupted. Charlotte stole from you. And instead of parenting her, you attacked me for caring. So I'm done caring. The look on her face was priceless, pure panic mixed with the dawning realization of just how much I've been carrying financially. Charlotte stormed into the kitchen. This is so unfair. You can't just stop paying for stuff. Watch me, I said. Only your mom made it clear, you're not my kids. So figure it out yourselves. Over the next week, reality hit them like a freight train. Samantha's paycheck couldn't stretch to cover what I've been handling. Charlotte's dance recital got canceled because the pain bounce Aiden soccer gear stayed dirty because no one had money for the laundromat. The twins started fighting, constantly stressed about their phones being dead and their friends asking why they couldn't hang out anymore. Charlotte couldn't even do her homework properly because I'd stopped paying for the internet. Samantha looked exhausted, working double shifts just to keep the lights on. Dark circles under her eyes, hair always messy, constantly stressed about making ends meet. The house felt different too. No more movie nights because no streaming services. No more.

My girlfriend said she wanted to be friends with benefits, so I treated her exactly like one. I've been planning Miranda's dream Valentine's Day for weeks. When she destroyed me over brunch, I just pulled out my phone to confirm the reservation at the restaurant she'd been dying to try, when she interrupted me. God, you're so clingy and needy. We need to talk, she said, pushing away the flowers I'd brought. I can't do this anymore. It's suffocating. You're always trying to be romantic, always wanting to do couple stuff. My heart broke. We're about to be a year, Miranda. Exactly why we need to set boundaries now. From now on, we're best friends who happen to sleep together. Treat me exactly like you treat Nate or will. No flowers or special treatment. Just buddies. I'm just someone you have sex with. She said it like I was pathetic for wanting more. Next to us, looked horrified. If that's what you want, I said quietly. She rolled her eyes. Finally. Maybe now you'll stop being so desperate and embarrassing. Valentine's Day arrived. Miranda texted asking about if we had plans. I responded that I was going to Nate's to watch the game. She could come if she wanted. Dead silence for an hour. Didn't we have a reservation? She finally asked. I reminded her that I don't make romantic reservations for my buddies. That night, she showed up at Nate's in a red dress and heels. Handed her a beer without Looking up from the TV and went back to the game. When she tried to sit next to me on the couch, I pointed to the recliner across the room. Dude, you're blocking the TV! Nate looked confused. Miranda's face went red. She spent the night watching us play video games and talk about sports. Her birthday came three weeks later. I got her what I got all my bros. A six pack of beer and buffalo wings from the sketchy place near campus. Stared at the grease stained container like it was radioactive. Where's my actual gift? She asked, voice shaking. That is your gift. Same thing I got will last month. Pretty good wings, too. But I'm your girlfriend. No, you're my friend who I occasionally sleep with. Your exact words. Didn't speak to me for two days. The real entertainment started at her company Spring Gala. She begged me to come, bought me a suit, and said it was important for her promotion. When her boss approached asking how long we've been together, I corrected him immediately, oh, we're not together. Her boss looked bewildered, but she said you were her boyfriend of 10 months. Nah, she doesn't do the relationship thing. We're buddies who hook up occasionally. She was actually just telling me how suffocating real relationships are. Miranda grabbed my arm so hard it left marks. Her coworkers started whispering. At her cousin's wedding in may, the disasters multiplied when they called for couples photos. I stayed seated, playing on my phone. We're not a couple, just friends with benefits, I explained to the photographer, who asked three times if I was sure. During the slow songs, I was at the bar with other guys talking about basketball, while she stood alone on the dance floor. Her family kept asking if we'd broken up. I explained cheerfully that Miranda didn't want to be together, just friends with benefits. Her grandmother nearly fainted. Her mom pulled her aside for a long conversation about self respect and not letting men use you. By month three, she was getting desperate. She tried to hold my hand in public. I'd give her a fist bump instead. When she leaned in for a kiss at dinner, I went for the high five. Bros don't make out at restaurants, I said. The waiter smirked.
NA

My narcissistic parents told my golden child brother that he could take my house and I could just live in a camper because I'm single and he has a wife and kids. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. After being homeless for two years, sleeping in parking lots, showering at truck stops, I finally saved enough to buy my own place. A small three bedroom house. Nothing fancy, but it was mine. The irony wasn't lost on me when I was homeless, begging them to let me park my camper in their driveway for just a few weeks. They called it an eye sore and told me to figure it out myself. My brother Dan actually laughed, calling me a homeless bum while his wife took pictures to mock me on social media. Now here they were, all four of them plus Dan's pregnant wife, going up at my door unannounced. They didn't even have my address. I never gave it to them. They must have followed me from work or something. Equally creepy. The moment I opened the door, they pushed past me like they owned the place. Dan's wife immediately started taking pictures again, but this time with dollar signs in her eyes. My parents were walking through my house like real estate agents, pointing at rooms, measuring spaces with their eyes, discussing which kid would get which bedroom. This is way too much space for just you, my mom declared, running her fingers along my kitchen. Counters. It's wasteful. My dad was already outside circling my property. Good luck. Size close to Dan's work, too. This will save us money on gas. That's when Dan pulled me aside into what used to be my peaceful living room. His wife and kids had already made themselves comfortable on my couch, feet up on my coffee table, tracking MUD across my carpet. Look, this is simple, Dan said, not even looking me in the eye. You don't need all this space. We're moving in next weekend. Can live in that camper out back. No discussion, no asking, no would you consider, or we'd really appreciate just informing me like I was a tenant getting evicted. The kids need stability, he continued. Olivia's pregnant again. We can't keep cramming everyone into mom and dad's place. I actually laughed. Absolutely not. That's when my mom marched back in from inspecting in my bedrooms. Daniel has four kids and another on the way. You're being selfish, living in all this space alone. My dad nodded from the doorway. It's time you helped family instead of just thinking about yourself. We raised you better than this. The audacity was breathtaking. These were the same people who wouldn't let me park in their driveway when I was literally homeless. Now they wanted to kick me out of my own house. I pulled out my phone and started recording. Let me get this straight. Do you want me to give up the house? I Bought with my own money. That I'm paying the mortgage on. So you can live here for free? We're not asking, Dan said, stepping closer like he was trying to intimidate me. We're telling you, family comes first. You owe us. After everything we've done for you. Everything you've done for me? I almost choked. You literally called me a homeless bum and refused to help when I was living in my truck. That was different. My mom snapped. You were irresponsible back then. Now you need to step up and do the right thing. Dan's wife finally spoke up from my couch. Besides, it's not

My girlfriend called me ugly in front of her friends and dumped me at a restaurant, leaving me to pay for the dinner. As she walked away, she loudly said, A guy like you should be grateful I even dated you. I smiled and calmly waited. Two hours later, she was begging me to come back. See, what Danielle didn't know was that I'd been planning to propose that night. The ring was literally in my jacket pocket when she started her little performance for her friends. I'd spent three months picking it out, saving up for my tech job, even asking her best friend what style she'd like. But here's the thing. Earlier that week, Danielle's marketing company had a complete system meltdown. Their servers crashed, client data was corrupted. Everything was chaos. Her boss, Edward, was panicking because they had a huge presentation for their biggest client. The next day, Danielle called me crying, begging for help. So I spent 14 hours straight rebuilding their entire network infrastructure, recovering lost files, and setting up new security protocols. I did it all remotely, working through the night while Danielle slept. When everything was fixed, Edward was so grateful, he told Danielle whoever solved this was getting a massive promotion and raise. The company had been about to lose their biggest account. Here's what Danielle didn't know. She had no idea I was the one who fixed everything. She thought they'd hired some expensive consultant because that's what Edward initially Told everyone before I asked him to keep my involvement quiet. I didn't want credit at her workplace. But Danielle being Danielle, immediately started taking credit. She told everyone she'd coordinated the technical response and managed the crisis. By the time I showed up for dinner, she'd apparently convinced half the office she was some kind of tech genius. Yes. So when she humiliated me in front of her friends, calling me a loser who should be grateful she dated me, I made a decision. I pulled out my phone right there at the table and sent one simple email to Edward. Hey, Edward, about that system fixed last week. Just wanted to clarify that Danielle wasn't involved in the technical. I handled the entire recovery personally as a favor to Danielle, but wanted to make sure credit went where it was due. Hope the Harris presentation went well. I attached screenshots of my remote access logs, knowing exactly when and how I'd fixed everything, along with the recovery scripts I'd written. Then I paid the 200 dollar Bill like a gentleman and went home. Two hours later, my phone started buzzing. Please call me. I can explain everything. I made a huge mistake then, and my boss wants to talk to you. What did you tell him then? I'm so sorry. We can work this out. Turns out Edward had called an emergency meeting the moment he got my email. He'd been suspicious about Danielle's sudden technical knowledge, but Hadn't questioned it. During the crisis, when he confronted her with my evidence, Danielle tried to claim we'd work together, that she'd

My fiance said, three days before our wedding, I need to tell you something. I think I'm making a mistake marrying you. I nodded, walked to my laptop, and canceled every single wedding vendor while she watched. Then I said, perfect timing. Now you won't have to worry about making a mistake anymore. What are you doing? She panicked. Exactly what you wanted, I replied, clicking through vendor after vendor. The catering? Canceled. The venue? Gone. The photographer? Done. She started crying. Steven, wait. I just meant I was having doubts. About marrying me? While texting your ex for six weeks? I interrupted pulling up her phone records I'd seen on our shared account that morning. Sean, right? Her face went white. You thought I didn't know? I've watched you smile at your phone every night for six weeks. I saw his name pop up during dinner last Tuesday, then Wednesday, then every single day since. I kept clicking. Florist? Canceled. DJ? Canceled. Rental company? Canceled. The flowers you picked out together? Gone. The playlist you spent and hours making with our songs? Delete it. The three tier cake with your precious initials carved in fondant? Someone else's problem now. Steven, please, can we just talk about this? We are talking. I'm talking about how you've been planning our wedding while secretly planning your exit strategy. I pulled up her text thread that I'd screenshotted weeks ago. Want me to read some highlights? I miss what we had, Sean. Sometimes I wonder what would have happened if we tried harder. Steven's a good guy, but he's not you. She buried her face in her hands. You went through my phone? Our shared phone plan. Kimberly. Every message shows up on the account summary. Basic technology. I turned the laptop screen toward her. $8,000 in deposits, completely gone. But that's still cheaper than hiring a divorce lawyer in two years. I never meant for this to happen. It just started as innocent, friendly conversation. Innocent? I scrolled through more messages, reading them aloud. You told him you dream about him every night. You said marrying me felt like settling for safe. You literally asked if he'd fight for you if you called off the wedding. Her crying stopped abruptly. The room went dead violent. That's right, sweetheart. I read that one, too. You were hoping he'd dramatically show up and stop the ceremony, weren't you? Like some cheesy romantic comedy movie where the girl gets off her feet. I continued the cancellation spree methodically. The string quartet you insisted we needed canceled your entire extended family's hotel reservations, canceled the rehearsal dinner at that ridiculously expensive steakhouse you absolutely had to have gone forever. My whole family flew in from Portland, Steven. What am I supposed to tell them now? Tell them the truth. Tell them you chose Sean over me, because that's exactly what you did when you started this emotional affair. I closed the laptop with a satisfying snap. Tell Sean he can have you, but he's paying for his own damn wedding. She just sat there in stunned silence, slowly realizing her romantic backup plan was now her only remaining plan. You know what the really funny part is? I genuinely would have worked through normal doubts with you. I would have postponed the wedding if you just been honest about your feelings. But instead, you chose to have a full blown emotional affair. I grabbed my keys and

My father demanded a DNA test for my grandfather's inheritance. I've been the family disappointment for 23 years, while my perfect older brother, Kyle got everything handed to him. When Grandpa died and left me his house in his will, dad absolutely lost it. There's no way that senile old man left you anything, he snarled, pacing around our kitchen like a king aged animal. You're probably not even my real son anyway. Your mother was sleeping around before we got married. My brother Kyle smirked from the corner. Yeah, remember how wild mom was back in college? Dad's got a point. My stepmother Linda chimed in with that fake sweet voice she always used. Honey, we just want what's fair for the real family. You understand, right? They gave me 48 hours to take a paternity test or they challenge the will in court. The whole extended family was already texting about it in the group chat, calling me a fraud and a bastard. Here's what none of them knew. I've been secretly taking care of Grandpa for the past two years while they all ignored him. Every single doctor's appointment when his arthritis got bad. Every grocery run when he couldn't drive anymore. Every lonely evening when he just wanted someone to talk to about grandma. I also knew about the second will he'd written just three months before he died. The next morning, dad changed the locks on Grandpa's house. When I showed up with my key. I couldn't get in. My stuff was piled on the front lawn in garbage bags. You're trespassing! Dad yelled from the window. This is family property until you prove you belong here. I called the police. Within an hour, Officer Ortiz was standing in the driveway reading the will. Sir, according to this legal document, your son owns this property. You're the one trespassing. Dad's face went red as they made him give me the new keys. The neighbors were all watching from their windows. Test day arrived at the family lawyer's office. The whole crew showed up like it was some kind of Celebration. Dad wore his best suit and kept checking his Rolex, probably already planning how to spend what he thought would be his inheritance money. Kyle brought his new girlfriend to show off. You're about to see how we handle fake family members, he told her loudly. Linda kept taking selfies, probably planning to post about their victory later. Uncle Robert and Aunt Deborah drove in from two states away just to witness my humiliation. The family group chat had been buzzing for days about this showdown. The DNA results came back after the longest hour of my life. 99.9% match. I was definitely Dad's biological son. Dad's victory dance and high fives with Kyle lasted exactly 10 seconds. However, the lawyer continued clearing his throat. There's something else the family needs to know about. Your grandfather actually left a second, more recent will that supersedes The first one, the room went dead silent. You could hear Linda's phone camera clicking. I pulled out my phone and played a video I'd recorded with Grandpa just weeks before he passed. His shaky but determined voice filled the entire office. To my son Harold and his family, who abandoned me in my final years, who only called when they needed money.

video_description: At dinner, my grandmother said to me,how was the trip l gave you as a gift? llooked at her confused. What trip? ldidn't receive anything.#reddit #ask #story
voice_to_text: At dinner, my grandmother said to me, how was the trip I gave you as a gift? I looked at her confused. What trip? I didn't receive anything. My grandmother's face darkened as she turned to my parents. The fifteen thousand dollar graduation trip to Europe I sent for Diego three months ago. The silence was deafening. My mom started fidgeting with her new designer purse, the one that mysteriously appeared last month along with matching shoes. My dad's gold chain suddenly felt heavier around his neck. And I noticed his expensive watch for the first time. We. We thought it would be better if my mom stamp her newly done nails, tapping nervously on the table. If what? Grandma's voice cut like ice. If you stole from your own son. That's when it all clicked. The sudden shopping sprees every weekend. My sister's new iPhone, iPad and MacBook. Family vacation to Cancun that I wasn't invited to. A kitchen renovation. Dad's new motorcycle sitting in our driveway. They'd stolen my graduation gift and spent it on themselves like it was Christmas morning. My sister Estania, who never worked a day in her life, was wearing earrings that cost more than my monthly gas station salary. Diamond studs that sparkled under the restaurant lights. She. I didn't even look up from her plate, too busy admiring her fresh manicure. You gave them everything their entire lives, I said quietly, my voice shaking with years of suppressed anger. And they took The one thing meant for me. The one thing I actually earned. Grandma stood up, her chair scraping against the floor loud enough to make nearby diners turn. 20 years I've watched you favor Estania over Diego like he's invisible. I sent that money specifically for him. With a letter explaining every detail of the trip I planned. My mom's face went white as paper. We never got a letter, I swear. Because you threw it away after cashing the check that had his name on it. The restaurant felt silent, despite other diners around us. Even the waiters seemed to sense the drama unfolding at our table. I couldn't hold back anymore. This explains everything. Why you suddenly had money for mom's Botox appointment and weekly spa days. Why dad bought that Harley Davidson he's been wanting for years. Why Estania got her nose job and started posting Instagram photos from five star hotels every single week. My grandmother's eyes widened with each revelation. Nose job? Instagram photos? Show me. I pulled out my phone and showed her Estania's recent posts. Bullside shots at luxury resorts in Miami. Designer shopping halls from Rodeo Drive. First class plane seats with champagne glasses. Expensive restaurant meals that cost more than I made in a week. All time stamped from the past three months. Right after my graduation, I've been working 70 hour weeks at the gas station. Just
NA

video_description: Manalo kaya sa huling resbak si Jepoy? HAHAHA #kentuwaan #fyp #foryoupage #funnyvideos #entertainment
voice_to_text: NA

Something you realized wasn't normal about your childhood. I thought everyone had to check their mattress for cockroaches before lying down until I was 15 years old and went to someone else's house for the first time. My morning routine involved shaking out my shoes because mice nested in them overnight. I also had to brush maggots off my backpack because the smell of rotting meat from somewhere deep in the house attracted flies that laid eggs on everything. Path to the bathroom required stepping on compressed newspapers that squished with mystery liquids that had been leaking from garbage bags since 2,011. Sometimes I'd hear crunching when I accidentally stepped on the bones of one of our cats that died and got buried under trash before anyone noticed. My breakfast came from sealed packages only because I once almost ate cereal that was full of ants. A lot of the time, I had to pee in bottles because the path to the toilet got blocked by the collapsing mountain of adult diapers my mother bought in bulk. Nobody in our house needed them, but she insisted they'd be worth money during the next pan. When Parker transferred to our school and picked me to be his history partner, I tried to convince him to switch. I knew eventually he'd want to meet outside school, but he had already turned in the paper with our names and said it would be too much hassle to change it now. He kept pushing. To work at my house I finally made up this whole story about my grandmother being sick. I said that she was super contagious and had something doctors couldn't figure out. He suggested his place instead and even offered to pick me up so I wouldn't have to take a bus. I said the bus didn't run to his neighborhood, even though really I just didn't wanna trap him in a car with my smell. I've been washing my clothes in the bathroom sink at school with the pink hand soap and drying them under the hand dryer, but the smell of decomposition and ammonia had gotten into the fabric permanently. Walking into his house broke my brain because my eyes didn't know what to do with all of the empty floor space it took.
NA

video_description: Lunch lady fired after giving foodto kids who couldn't pay#news #breakingnews #usa
voice_to_text: A school cafeteria worker admits she did wrong and she understands why she was fired. For 14 years, Debbie Salzman worked as a beloved lunch lady here at Denver Place Elementary School in Wilmington. She says she would upgrade the lunch of a child who didn't have enough money or give them extra food if they said they were still hungry. If they didn't have enough money on their account, they would get a cheese sandwich instead. Friend that got a free lunch that would come back and say, Miss Debbie, I'm still hungry. Didn't you get your belly full for supper last night? And you don't know how many times I heard they didn't have supper that night. Salesman says she kept posted note IOU's and paid out of her own pocket for kids. But the district suspended and terminated her this February for, quote, not keeping track of a register and providing food to her grandchildren without payment, end quote. Salesman admits to giving her grandchildren extra food, too, but says it wasn't just them. I broke the rule. I'm the one that broke the rule.

My fiance said my pregnancy updates were too disgusting to listen to, so I never gave him another one. I've been with Jerry for four years. When he humiliated me during our baby shower at this fancy country club he wanted to go to, my cousin asked why my pupils look so red. And I explained that this morning I threw up so hard that the blood vessels in my eyes burst. Jerry exploded on me. Shut up. Nobody wants to hear about your bloody eyes and vomit. Can you just be pregnant without making it everyone else's problem? It's revolting. The entire room went silent. His own sister tried to intervene, but he doubled down. What, I'm supposed to pretend all this isn't gross? Yesterday she described how her nipples are leaking. Last week it was about her discharge and cellulite. We get it. You're pregnant. Your body is doing nasty things. His mom gasped. Jerry, she's carrying your child. That doesn't mean I need to hear about every disgusting thing happening to her. This is supposed to be a happy day and she's making me lose my appetite. I sat down my drink. You know what, you're absolutely right. I won't discuss you with any more updates, Jerry. He looked at me surprised, then pleased. Finally. Thank you. See, not that hard to keep all that private. Two days later, Jerry found me getting dressed for my 20 week anatomy scan. What time is the appointment? I'll drive Oh, I'm going alone. I don't wanna subject you to disgusting pregnancy stuff. His face scrunched up. But we find out if it's a boy or girl today. Yeah. And that involves the technician pressing a wand covered in gel all over my stomach while we look at our baby's private parts on his screen. Plus, they measure all the organs. Pretty gross medical stuff. That's different. No, it's not. You said pregnancy details revolt you. I'm respecting that. I took an Uber and when he showed up, I made him wait outside the doctor's office. Next day, his mom called him crying tears of joy. You're having a boy. He looks perfect. And you better have already apologized to your fiance. Jerry put the phone down and stormed into the bedroom. You said the doctor said we have to wait another few weeks before gender shows. I only said that not to disgust you. I didn't want you losing your appetite. You can't keep the gender from me. I'm not keeping anything. I'm protecting you from revolting pregnancy talk, just like you asked. When people asked about baby names, I discussed them enthusiastically with everyone except Jerry. Our friends knew we were considering James. His parents knew about Thomas. His brother knew about William. Why won't you tell me the names you're considering? Discussing the baby requires mentioning pregnancy. That's off limits. Remember, this is insane. This is literally what you demanded. At 28 weeks, I, I started experiencing Concerning symptoms, my feet swelled so badly that when I pressed them, the indent stayed like memory foam and my vision kept getting black spots. I went to the hospital alone when they diagnosed me with preeclampsia and admitted me for monitoring. I texted everyone except Jerry. He found out when his brother called asking why he wasn't at the hospital. You're in the hospital and didn't tell me medical details about pregnancy or TMI. You said so yourself. You could lose the baby and you could get so grossed out by looking at me. You'd call me disgusting and the stress would definitely make me lose it. He went quiet when the doctor scheduled my C section for 36 weeks due to complications. I didn't tell Jerry. I informed his family, my family, our friends, everyone but him. The baby is coming next Tuesday, his sister told him. Jerry called me frantically. Tuesday. You're having our son on Tuesday. Yep. Didn't want to discuss you with talk about them cutting through my abdomen layers and pulling a baby out of my uterus. I need to request time off. Why? You don't want to see gross pregnancy stuff. It's literally the birth of my child.

My sister removed my seven year old daughter's hair, leaving her bald. Now you really look like your loser father. While my nieces were laughing. The next day her account was frozen and the bank for closed on her house. For three years, I've been financially supporting my younger sister Jessica to her divorce. I paid her mortgage, utilities, groceries, everything so she and her daughters wouldn't struggle. Jessica worked at a hair salon, but barely made enough. Over time, I noticed her attitude. She never said thank you, only criticized our life. If we bought a car, she'd say we were showing off. If we took Isabella on vacation, she'd complain that some of us aren't so lucky. Isabella, my daughter, has always been sweet with long, shiny brown hair. Sometimes she'd come home saying Aunt Jessica scolded me or Aunt Jessica said my dress was ugly. Those comments bothered me. Everything changed one Saturday. Isabella was invited to a friend's birthday party and wanted to look like a princess. I decided to take her to Jessica for a special haircut. I called and said, make Isabella look like a princess. I'll leave extra money. Jessica responded dryly, alright, leave her with me, but don't come too late. I dropped Isabella off at Jessica's house. Isabella was happy in her pink dress and sparkling shoes. I kissed her forehead and said I'd be back in a few hours. When I returned at five PM, I heard heartbreaking crying as I approached. I heard Jessica shouting, now you look like your father's failure. Bald and horrible, just like him! Then came laughter, Jessica's laugh and her daughter's giggles. I slammed the door open. Isabella was sitting in a chair with her head lowered. At her feet was a pile of hair, scattered like trash. When she lifted her face, my world collapsed. She was completely bald. Called Jessica had shaved her head, leaving not a single strand. My little princess had red eyes from crying, her face filled with shame. Jessica stood beside her with a razor, laughing. Her daughters were pointing at Isabella, mocking her look. She looks like an egg, Sophia said, laughing. How ugly! Added Lucia. I hugged Isabella tightly. She clung to me, shaking and threw her sobs. Said daddy, why did she do this to me? I just wanted to look pretty. What did you do to my daughter? I roared at Jessica. She stopped laughing, but didn't seem sorry. Calm down, Antonio, it was just a joke. I told her I was giving her a modern cut. She looks unique, she said with a mocking smile. A joke? You shaved my daughter's head! You humiliated her! She shrugged. Don't be dramatic, it's just hair. Plus that girl is always showing off with her long hair. Like my daughters aren't as beautiful. She's a 7 year old girl who wanted to feel pretty. You did this out of envy! Jessica exploded. Don't come at me! With envy crap. You're always showing off your perfect life while I'm struggling alone.

My wife gave me silent treatment for 20 days. So on day 21, I made it permanent. 20 days of silence. That's what my wife decided I deserved after I suggested she help with household responsibilities instead of treating me like her personal butler. But here's the thing about playing the silent treatment card. Sometimes the other person decides they prefer the quiet. I finished a 12 hour shift and walked into what looked like a tornado hit our kitchen. Did. She's piled high. Take out containers scattered everywhere. And her on the couch scrolling through her phone. I made the apparently unforgivable mistake of saying, hey, think you could give me a hand cleaning up before dinner? The look she gave me could frozen hell over. Excuse me? I work, too. I'm not your maid. I never said you were. I thought we could tackle this together since we both live here. That's when she stood up, grabbed her purse, and delivered the line that would define the next three weeks. Figure it out yourself. And don't expect me to talk to you until you learn some respect. Front door slammed so hard it rattled the windows. When she came back two hours later, I thought we'd have a normal conversation. I was wrong. She walked past me like I was invisible and went straight to the bedroom. Day two rolled around and still nothing. I tried the reasonable approach. If I came across wrong yesterday, we should talk. She poured her coffee, walked past me, and left for work without acknowledging I existed. By day 5, I realized what this was. This wasn't about dishes or respect. This was control. She decided freezing me out would make me grovel and apologize for something I shouldn't apologize for. Day 7 was when something clicked. I was eating a sandwich, watching her perform her silent tantrum routine, and I started laughing. Here was a grown woman who thought giving me the cold shoulder was going to break me down. Instead, it was showing me exactly who I'd married. By day 10, the house had gotten remarkably peaceful. No arguing about whose turn it was to take out trash. No passive aggressive comments about the dishwasher. No dramatic sighs when I wanted to watch sports. I was starting to see the upside. Day 15 brought reinforcements. Her sister called asking if everything was okay because my wife seemed stressed. Told her everything was fine. I was giving my wife the space she'd requested. When her sister tried to dig deeper, I said, she knows how to end this anytime she wants an adult conversation. But here's what she didn't realize during her tantrum. I was using this time to think about what my life had become and what I wanted it to be. Day 20 arrived with her pacing around like a caged animal, looking at me with this.

My own mother abandoned me at the airport when I was just 15, all to enjoy a luxurious vacation with her new husband and his kids. You can figure it out. She shrugged. I stood there watching her walk away with her perfect little blended family, dragging their matching designer suitcases toward the gate. She didn't even look back. Not once. I had $23 in my pocket, a dead phone charge charger, and absolutely nowhere to go in this massive airport. That's when I remembered the business card tucked in my wallet. The one with the fancy logo I've been carrying around for three years. My Aunt Sarah's restaurant card. The sister my mom had been bad mouthing my entire life, calling her a jealous failure. Sarah's a pathetic loser, mom always said. She's jealous of our success and stability. Buddy, don't believe anything she tells you about our family. But standing there alone in JFK Terminal 4, watching families rush past me with their vacation excitement, I figured I had nothing left to lose. I found a payphone. Yes still exist in airports. And dialed the number with shaking fingers. It rang twice before a warm, professional voice answered. Bella Vista restaurant. This is Sarah speaking. Aunt Sarah, it's Maya. I'm. I'm in really big trouble right now. The silence lasted forever. Then, in a completely different tone. Baby girl? Maya, where are you? Are you safe? What happened? I started crying. Right there in the middle of the Busy terminal. Mom left me at the airport. She took her new husband and his kids on vacation to Hawaii and just abandoned me here. What terminal are you at? I'm coming to get you right now. You don't understand. I'm at JFK in New York. You're all the way in Chicago. I can't ask you to. Maya, Honey, listen to me carefully. I have three successful restaurants now. I'm not the broke failure your mother told you I was. Exactly where you are. I'm getting on the next available flight. Four hours later, I watched a confident woman in designer jeans and a cashmere coat rush through the arrivals gate, scanning the crowd frantically. She looked exactly like mom, but her eyes were kind instead of cold. When she spotted me, she started running. I've been waiting 10 years for the phone call, she whispered, hugging me so tight I could barely breathe. I've tried reaching you so many times, but your mother blocked every single attempt. To ride to her luxury hotel suite was completely surreal. Sarah explained everything while ordering room service. How she built a successful restaurant empire from nothing. How she been sending birthday cards and Christmas gifts that mom apparently threw away unopened. How she'd even hired a family lawyer once to try for visitation rights. Your mother told everyone in our family

My wife asked me to leave our home. I didn't argue. I just closed our joint accounts and changed the locks instead. Last Tuesday, I received divorce papers from my wife, Natalia, after four years of marriage. But she didn't deliver them herself. Her new boyfriend, Gabriel, showed up at my doorstep with the envelope. Natalia wants you out by Friday, he told me with arrogant, confident. Find somewhere else to stay. I looked at this guy, who'd clearly been sleeping with my wife, and simply replied, okay. He probably expected me to break down or punch him. Instead, I closed the door and started making calls. First to my lawyer, then to the bank. What? Gabriel and Natalia didn't know the house was solely in my name. I bought it before we married with inheritance money and never added her to the title. Gabriel had been living there for a month while I was away for work. Natalia claimed he was an acquaintance going through tough time. Complete lie. When he demanded I find somewhere else to stay. He was trying to kick me out of my own house. By Wednesday morning, I changed all the locks. That afternoon, I canceled Gabriel's access to everything. Netflix, Spotify, Amazon Prime. He'd even added himself to my 90 Dollar Family Gym membership. Canceled that too. Thursday night, Gabriel appeared, banging on the door. What the hell is going on? Why did you change the locks? Cause this is my house. I Replied from inside, Natalia can get her things, but you have to leave. She's my partner. Now we're together. Perfect. Go be together somewhere else. His tantrum was epic, screaming that I was vengeful that he had rights. Meanwhile, I recorded everything. I texted Natalia, you have 48 hours to collect your belonging. Gabriel is not welcome here. Her response you can't do this. Gabriel lives here now. Check the property title. He's nowhere on it. The next morning, Gabriel's lawyer showed up, claiming Gabriel had tendency rights because as he'd lived there over 30 days. I showed him the recording of Gabriel screaming that he was there as my wife's partner, not a tenant. There's no lease, no rent payments, no contributions, I explained, showing the property title with me as sole owner. The lawyer went pale and left quickly.

When did your wife realize you weren't just an unemployed? Twitch chatter. Sarah came home from her 12 hour hospital shift to find me in the same spot at my computer. Twitch stream on one monitor, spreadsheets minimized on the other. She dropped her bag with that familiar exhausted sound. Mike, eight months. You've been unemployed for eight months watching gamers play Fortnite? My mom keeps asking if you're depressed. I quickly switched tabs as she approached. Just keeping myself busy. Busy? You're watching someone build a virtual house. She saw my chat messages and actively participating. This isn't a hobby anymore. It's an addiction. What she didn't see were the other tabs supplier emails from China, Shipping trackers, customer service responses. The Twitch streams were just background noise while I managed orders, adjusted Facebook ad campaigns, and negotiated with suppliers about delayed shipments. My sister's husband just bought a rental property, Sarah continued. Meanwhile, I'm telling people you're between opportunities. Truth was, my dropshipping business was finally profitable after 6 months of testing products. Gaming accessories of all things. Mouse pads with LED edges, custom keyboard caps, able management systems. Stuff I found by watching what streamers complained about. Can you at least come to dinner tomorrow? Pretend you're trying. Her family dinner was torture. Her brother described his new BMW. Her father offered me a pity job at his hardware store. Again, Sarah deflected questions about our future, saying we were figuring things out. Maybe he could drive For Uber, her mother suggested. Loud enough for me to hear. Everything unraveled because the doorbell camera notification. Sarah was showing her sister our ring footage to prove our neighbor's dog kept getting in our yard. She scrolled too far back and saw something odd. Delivery drivers. Dozens of them. Every single day. Mike, why are so many packages coming to our house? Her sister leaned in. Are you shopping addicts? Is that why you're broke? Their returns, I said quickly. But Sarah kept scrolling. The packages were being picked up, not dropped off. Different drivers collecting them. What the hell is this? I couldn't hide it anymore. Opened my laptop and showed her the Shopify dashboard. 300 orders this month. Inventory spreadsheet showing zero stock because everything shipped directly from suppliers to customers. You're selling things? Gaming accessories. Mouse pads, mostly. She stared at the revenue numbers. Last month was my best yet. Enough to cover our mortgage twice. But you don't have any products here. They ship from the supplier. I handle marketing and customer service. I showed her the Facebook ads running in the background, the email campaigns, the abandoned cart sequences. This. This is real money. I opened the business checking account. Six months of deposits from Shopify. Not fortune, but solid middle class income from selling LED mouse pads to gamers. Why didn't you tell me? Remember when I tried explaining dropshipping? You said it was a pyramid scheme for people who watch too many YouTube gurus because you explained it while watching someone play Minecraft at 2:00am, her sister was reading over her shoulder. Wait, he's been running a business this whole time? Sarah scrolled through customer emails, reviews, the business registration, tax documents, everything legit, just invisible. I've been telling everyone you're unemployed. I cried to my therapist about supporting you. I know my dad offered you minimum wage out of pity. I make more than his offer in three days selling mouse pads. Her phone started buzzing, family group chat exploding as her sister shared the news. Her dad asking how online selling actually worked. Her mom confused about what dropshipping meant. Why all the secrecy, though? It wasn't supposed to be secret. But every time I tried explaining, you'd see me on the computer and assume I was wasting time. Eventually, I stopped trying.

My best friend told me I was too clingy and needed to get my own life, so I did exactly that. Penny cornered me at lunch Monday, Monica and Christina flanking her like bodyguards. Jenna, this is an intervention, she announced. Monica snorted. You text me literally every five minutes. You waited outside my math class yesterday, even though yours is across campus. You got weird when I went to Monica's sleepover without you. She crossed her arms. It's honestly embarrassing. Monica's best friend has her own life, her own friends. They're independent. You're, like, obsessed with me or something. Christina laughed. No offense, but it's giving desperate. Penny shrugged. You need to get your own life and stop making me her entire personality. I felt my face burn, but looking at Penny's expression, I realized she was serious. Had I really been that bad? After my parents divorced, penny was my rock. Maybe I'd held on too tight. Maybe I depended on her too much emotionally. I'm sorry, I said quietly. I didn't realize I was making you uncomfortable. Starting Tuesday, I gave her exactly what she asked for. No morning texts. Said they were too much. I saw her in the hallway and just smiled instead of running over. She wanted space. At lunch, I accepted the Art Girls invitation to sit with them. They've been asking for weeks, and I'd always said no to stay with penny. They were genuinely excited to have me. Finally, Lorelai said, We've been wanting to be friends forever. But you were always with penny. They were so welcoming, teaching me their inside jokes, including me in their group chat. Thursday morning hurt the most. We bought tickets together weeks ago for the school's talent show. Front row seats to support our friends band. I sat there alone, saving her seat with my backpack until the lights dimmed. She never came. During intermission, I saw her Instagram story. She was at Starbucks with Monica and Christina, laughing over Frappuccinos. The caption read, so much better than boring school events. My eyes burned with tears. I wouldn't let fall. She'd known and didn't show up. And worse, she seemed happier without me. I deleted the text I'd started typing, asking where she was. She wanted space, and clearly she was thriving with it. After the show, I joined the drama club, something penny had always made fun of. When Romeo from drama asked if I wanted to practice lines after school, I said yes. Immediately. I posted a selfie with him captioned new drama partner with heart emojis. Penny viewed it in 10 seconds, but didn't like it. Lorelai invited me to a party Friday. Penny will be there, too, she mentioned. At the party, I stayed with my new friends, but kept checking on penny discreetly. She was with Monica and Christina by the pool. When Monica loudly said, at least you finally got rid of your stalker. I pretend ended not To hear penny laughed along with them, that stung. But if that's how she felt, I'd respect it. Everything crashed down Tuesday. I was heading to art club when I heard someone crying in the bathroom. Harsh, painful sobs. My heart knew it was penny before my brain did. Soph, are you okay? I asked softly through the door. Leave me alone, Jenna. I don't want to guilt you into caring about my problems. What? Penny, please let me in. The door unlocked. I look destroyed. Mascara streaking, eyes swollen. My parents are getting divorced, she whispered. Dad's been cheating for months. I found out Sunday night. My heart broke. I pulled her into my arms, feeling her whole body shake. She told me through gasps how she'd wanted to call me Sunday night when her dad moved out, but Monica had convinced her not to be a hypocrite. How she'd seen my Instagram.

What's the most ridiculous rule your parents made that completely backfired? Last summer, my parents decided we needed a technology free family bonding road trip to Yellowstone. They announced this planet dinner looking way too proud of themselves. No phones, no tablets, no Nintendo Switch, dad declared. We're going to reconnect as a family and appreciate nature. My 16 year old sister Denki and I just stared at them in horror. A week long road trip with no electronics? They might as well have suggested we travel by covered wagon. But what if there's an emergency? Denki asked, already plotting. We'll have our phones for emergencies only, mom said. But they'll be locked in the glove compartment. The night before we left, Denki and I held an emergency sibling meeting. We were not going down without a fight. Operation Digital Rebellion is a go! She whispered, pulling out a duffel bag full of contraband electronics. We spent hours hiding devices throughout our luggage. Denki sown a secret pocket into her pillow for her phone. I hollered out a thick book and stuffed my Nintendo Switch inside. We even hit a portable charger inside a bag of trail mix. Day one started with Dad's enthusiastic announcement. Isn't this great, kids? Look at all this beautiful scenery. Let's play the license plate game. Wow, dad, A Nebraska plate! Riveting. Denki deadpanned while secretly texting her boyfriend through her pillow. By hour three, mom was getting suspicious because we were being unusually cooperative. About her car games. Little did she know, I was playing Pokemon under a blanket while pretending to nap. You kids seem awfully quiet back there, she said, turning around. Just enjoying the family bonding, mom, I said, quickly shoving my switch under my fake book. Denki had gotten creative with her rebellion. She downloaded audiobooks and was listening through earbuds she threaded through her hoodie strings. Every time mom asked her a question, she pretend to be deep in thought about nature. By day two, we'd established an elaborate system. Denki would be the lookout while I game, then we'd switch. We communicated through coughs and sneezes. That meant parents incoming or coast is clear. The funniest part was when dad stopped at this scenic overlook and insisted we all take a family photo. While he was setting up his camera, Denki was frantically trying to finish a level on her hidden phone game. Denki, Smile! Dad called out, just a second. I'm appreciating the natural beauty, she said, thumbs flying across her screen. Our rebellion reached peak chaos on day three when we discovered the hotel had terrible Wi-Fi. Denki had a complete meltdown because she couldn't upload her secret vacation selfies to Instagram. The bathroom has better no! She whispered to me during dinner. So there we were, taking turns hiding in the hotel bathroom, desperately trying to get one bar of service while our parents thought we had digestive issues from the road trip snacks. You Kids have been spending a lot of time in the bathroom, mom observed suspiciously. Must be all that healthy trail mix you packed, I said innocently, while Denki was literally sitting on the bathroom floor trying to connect to Wi-Fi. Day 4 brought disaster. Dad decided to surprise us with a spontaneous hike and grabbed our backpacks to carry water bottles. That's when he discovered Denki's secret phone charging station she'd set up using the car's USB port. What is this?

I took everything that's mine when my roommate asked me to move out. So I was living with this girl, Megan, who I thought was my friend. We'd known each other since freshman year. And when she said she found this perfect apartment and wanted me to sign the lease with her, I jumped at it. Five months of splitting everything, 50 50, doing dishes like good little roommates, never fighting over anything. Then one random Tuesday, I get this text while I'm at my job at the campus bookstore. Hey, we need to talk when you get home. That's never good, right? So I'm driving back thinking maybe she wants to talk about whose turn it is to buy toilet paper or something stupid like that. But when I walk in, she's sitting on our couch with this weird serious face she starts with. So I've been thinking and I already know I'm screwed. She tells me she doesn't think living together is working out and that she already talked to our landlord about me moving out by January 1st. I'm just sitting there like, what the hell? Because we literally never fought. I paid my half of everything on time. I cleaned up after myself and I even bought all the good stuff for our place. But she's acting like I'm some nightmare roommate who's been making her life miserable. I don't argue because honestly, why would I want to live with someone who doesn't want me there? So I tell her, fine, I'll start looking for a new place. She seems relieved like she was expecting me to throw a fit or something. That night I'm lying in bed thinking about how I need to pack everything and that's when it hits me. I look around our apartment and realize I bought literally everything that makes it nice. 50 inch TV mounted on the wall. Mine, the leather couch were always watching Netflix on. I saved up three paychecks for that thing. The coffee maker, the good plates instead of paper ones, the router for our internet, even the freaking shower curtain. Next morning I tell Megan I'll be taking all my stuff when I move out. She just says, okay, like it's no big deal. I don't think she really thought about what that meant. I spent the next two weeks apartment hunting and found this decent one bedroom across town. On moving day, I rented one of those big U Haul trucks because I knew I'd need it. Megan wasn't even home, which was probably for the best. I started with the obvious stuff like my clothes and my desk. Then I unplugged the TV and carefully took it down from the wall. I wrapped up the coffee maker, packed all the dishes I'd bought from target and loaded the couch onto the truck with help from my buddy Jake. The router was the last thing I grabbed. I unpacked all the Ethernet cables and took The whole setup. As I'm walking out with it, I realised she's going to have zero internet until she gets her own. But here's the thing that really made me laugh. When I was packing up the kitchen stuff, I realised I'd bought all the cooking supplies too, the pans, the good knife set, even the can opener. I left her with basically nothing except a mini fridge and some random cups she had from high school. By the time I finished loading everything, the apartment looked like nobody had ever lived there, just empty rooms with some random junk scattered around that wasn't worth taking. I drive to my new place. Feeling pretty good about myself. I'm unpacking when my phone starts blowing up. First it's texts, then calls. Megan is absolutely losing it. What the hell did you do to the apartment? She screams. When I finally pick up, it's completely empty. I tell her calmly that I took everything I paid for, just like I said I would. She she starts yelling about how she looks like an idiot because her friends were supposed to come over that night and now there's nowhere to sit and nothing to watch. You can't just take everything, she says. How am I supposed to explain this? I remind her that she literally said okay when I told her I was taking my stuff. She hangs up on me.
NA
