I leaked fake baby names to family. So I'm like 6 months pregnant and my husband Kyle and I have been keeping our baby name super secret. We've picked Emmitt for a boy and Nora for a girl. But every single family gathering turns into this crazy interrogation session about what we're naming the kid. My mother in law, Janet, is the worst. She'll literally corner me by the kitchen sink and be like, just give me a hint, honey. I promise I won't tell anyone. Meanwhile, she's already told half the neighborhood that I'm having twins because she misheard something at dinner three weeks ago. Then there's my sister Emma, who keeps suggesting names like Braxton and Nivea because apparently normal names aren't creative enough anymore. And don't even get me started on Kyle's brother who keeps pushing for family names. He wants us to name our kid after their dead Uncle Mortimer. Like, dude, it's 2025, not 1825. The breaking point was last Sunday at my in law's house. I'm trying to eat my potato salad in peace when Janet goes, I have a feeling it's going to be Theodore. Doesn't she look like she's carrying a Theodore? And then Emma chimes in with, no way. That baby is definitely a Paisley. Meanwhile, Kyle's cousin starts going on about how we should honor the family tradition and Kyle's dad is nodding along like this is some kind of democracy vote. I looked at Kyle across the table and He had this look like he wanted to crawl under the furniture. That's when I decided enough was enough. So I stood up, put my hands on my belly, all dramatic like, and announced, you know what, you guys have been so invested in this, I think you deserve to know. Everyone got quiet real fast. We've narrowed it down to three names, I said, making eye contact with each person. For a boy, we're thinking either Bartholomew, Nebuchadnezzar or Gaylord. And for a girl, it's between Brunilda, Bertha or Methuselah. Kyle nearly choked on his ice.

Cops, what's the most bullshit sounding excuse you got that actually turned out to be true? I got the call around 9:00am. Silver sedan crashed through the Henderson family's white picket fence on Maple Street. Standard fender Bender. I figured probably some soccer mom texting while backing out her driveway. When I pulled up, I saw this beat up Honda Civic sitting halfway through the fence, front bumper buried in Mrs. Henderson's prize winning rose bushes. Driver door was hanging wide open and this lanky 20 something kid was pacing around the car like he was having a panic attack. The second he saw my patrol car, he sprinted over waving his hands above his head. Officer, thank god you're here. I didn't do it. I swear on my mother's grave I didn't do it. I stepped out already reaching for my notepad. Kid reeked of panic, sweat but no alcohol. His eyes were clear. Pupils normal size, not high either. Alright, son, just calm down and tell me what happened. That's when he said the most ridiculous thing I'd ever heard in my career. My dog drove the car into the fence. I stopped writing and looked at him. Come again. My dog, Bruno. He somehow shifted it into gear and crashed it. The kid was pointing frantically at this massive golden retriever sitting in the driver's seat, tongue hanging out, looking proud as punch. I rubbed my forehead. Your dog drove your car? Well, not drove exactly, but Yeah, I just ran inside to grab my wallet, left the engine running because I was only gonna be 30 seconds. Bruno must have jumped up front and stepped on something. I was about to start the whole drunk driving test routine when the kid kept talking. Look, I know it sounds crazy, but Mrs. Henderson has cameras. She's got that ring doorbell thing and it points right at her driveway. You can see everything. Now, I was curious, in 17 years.

What is something that you swear happened but you have no proof and nobody believes you? I was 15 when my cousin Layla came to stay at our house for a few months. Her parents were getting divorced and things were pretty messy. Layla was identical to her twin sister Lena, but they were complete opposites. Layla was quiet, loved painting and spent hours in our spare room just drawing these amazing pictures. Lena was loud, crazy, and once got suspended for dying her hair bright green just to annoy her math teacher. Even though they looked exactly the same, everyone could tell them apart. It wasn't hard if you knew them. Layla would sit in the corner at family dinners, barely talking. Lena would be standing on her chair telling jokes and making everyone laugh. They were like two different people in the same body. For three months, Layla and I shared my bedroom. We became super close. She taught me how to paint these weird abstract things with purple rivers and yellow skies that didn't make sense but somehow looked amazing. We had this inside joke where we'd whisper dragonfly dreams to each other. When adults were being boring, she kept journals everywhere, little notebooks filled with sketches and poems about feeling invisible. Then one day in March, Layla said she was going home early. Her dad picked her up on a Tuesday morning. She hugged me tight and said, thanks for everything. I. I watched her car. Drive away, thinking I'd see her again soon. Three weeks later, we got invited to Layla's birthday party. Mom and I drove over, excited to surprise her. But when the door opened, I knew something was wrong immediately. The girl standing there wasn't Layla. Everyone else acted normal, her parents, her friends even, and my mom. They all said it was Layla celebrating her 16th birthday. But I knew it was Lena. She stood differently, talked louder, kept flipping her hair. Lena always did that annoying hair flip thing. I whispered dragonfly dreams to her when we were alone by the cake table.

I asked my brother not to bring his girlfriend to my wedding. My brother Jake has this girlfriend named Becca who literally cannot stand not being the center of attention for 5 minutes. Every family dinner, every holiday, every gathering, she finds a way to make it about her. Last Thanksgiving, she announced she was pregnant right when my dad was about to carve the Turkey. Turns out she wasn't even pregnant. Just wanted to see everyone's reactions. So when I was planning my wedding to my fiance, Ryan, I knew I had to do something about the Becca situation. This was going to be my one day, the one day that was supposed to be about me and Ryan starting our life together. I called Jake about three months before the wedding. Hey, so about the wedding, I started. I need to ask you something kind of awkward. What's up, he said. And I could hear him eating cereal in the background. I really don't want Becca there. I know that sounds harsh, but she always makes everything about herself and I just can't deal with that stress on my wedding day. The line went quiet for like 10 seconds and Jake exploded. Are you serious right now you're uninviting my girlfriend from your wedding? I'm not uninviting her because she was never invited in the first place. The invitation was just for you. That's the same thing. We've been together for two years. He's basically family. I tried. To explain that it wasn't personal, that I just wanted one drama free day. But Jake wasn't having it. He said if Becca couldn't come, then he wouldn't come either. I told him that was his choice, hoping he'd change his mind. He didn't. But here's where it gets crazy. The day of my wedding, I'm getting my makeup done in the bridal suite when my cousin Madison bursts in. Uh, you need to see this, she says, shoving her phone in my face. It's Becca's Instagram story. She's posted like 15 videos of herself getting all dressed up, doing her makeup, picking out jewelry. The cat.

I've let my boyfriend tell a friend to find her own ride home from the beach. So my boyfriend Jake and I had been dating for 8 months. His friend Emma had been part of that group since high school. She was one of those girls who was super close with all the guys. And honestly, I didn't think much of it at first. She seemed nice enough and Jake always said they were just friends. But over the past few weeks, I started noticing things, little things that made me uncomfortable, like how she'd always sit next to Jake when we hung out in groups, how she'd touch his arm when she laughed at his jokes, how she'd text him at weird hours about random stuff. The beach trip was supposed to be fun. It was Jake's birthday weekend and we'd planned this whole day with about 10 of his friends. Everyone was supposed to drive themselves or coordinate rides beforehand. The morning of the trip, Jake got a call from Emma. Her car, I was in the shop and she needed a ride. No big deal, right? Jake said we could pick her up on the way. When we got to her place, she came bouncing out in this tiny bikini that left nothing to the imagination. She threw her beach bag in the back and climbed into the passenger seat of Jake's car. The passenger seat where I usually sat. I was standing there like an idiot. Holding my own beach bag while she was already buckling herself in and adjusting the mirrors. Jake looked at me and shrugged like this was totally normal. Sorry, babe, she called. Shotgun, he said with this awkward laugh. I squeezed into the back seat, feeling like a third wheel in my own boyfriend's car. The whole drive there, Emma was playing her music, talking about inside jokes I wasn't part of and basically acting like I wasn't even there. When we got to the beach, things got worse. She'd ask Jake to put sunscreen on her back. She'd splash him in the water while I was setting up our spot. She'd lean against him when we were all sitting in the sand talking about memories from high school. That always seemed to exclude me. The breaking point came when we were all playing volleyball.

I refused full custody of my daughter after my husband asked for a divorce. My ex husband, Jake, had this perfect plan mapped out. He'd work his fancy job while I stayed home with Mia. Since she was born seven years later, I barely remembered who I was before diapers and goldfish crackers. When Jake came home that Tuesday night, he didn't even sit down. Just stood by the kitchen counter, still in his work clothes, and said he wanted a divorce. No warning, no fight beforehand, nothing. He said he'd been thinking about it for months. I felt like someone punched me in the stomach. But then he kept talking. He said since I didn't have a job or income, he figured I'd want him to take me a most of the time. You know, so she could have stability. He even had this whole speech ready about how I could see her every other weekend and Wednesday nights. That's when it clicked. He planned this whole thing while I was home making lunches and helping with homework. He was probably talking to lawyers, making sure everything worked out perfect for him. I asked him if he met someone else. He got all defensive and said it wasn't about that. But he wouldn't look at me when he said it. Just kept staring at his phone. The next few weeks were hell. Jake moved into his brother's spare room, but still came by every morning to help Mia get Ready for school, acting like nothing changed. Meanwhile, I'm googling divorce lawyers at 2:00am and crying in the target parking lot. My mom kept calling, saying I needed to fight for custody, that any good mother would. But here's what nobody understood. I was exhausted. Not just tired. Completely burnt out. Seven years of being the only parent who knew where the Band Aid drawer was or what Mia's teacher's name was. Jake never once took her to a doctor's appointment, never knew her friends names, never did bedtime without me. But suddenly he wanted to be dad of the year. So when our lawyers met, Jake looked shocked when I said I agreed to his custody plan. His lawyer even asked if I was sure. Like they expect

I told my child's teacher I may charge back slash cancel orders. My seven year old daughter came home from school last Tuesday with this massive folder of stuff, not homework, not art projects, a freaking catalog, 20 pages of overpriced junk that nobody actually needs. Mom, we have to order something for the school fundraiser, Emma said, bouncing around the kitchen. Mrs. Allen said every family needs to participate. I flipped through the catalog, 30 dollar wrapping paper that you can get at Dollar Tree for two bucks. Cookie dough for 40 dollars that makes 12 cookies. A 60 dollar candle that probably smells like vanilla and false hope. Prices were absolutely insane. But here's the thing, Emma's school had been struggling. They'd cut art programs, music class was down to once a week and the playground equipment looked like it survived a tornado. So I figured, okay, I'll buy something small to help out. I ordered a 25 dollar pizza kit because Emma loves making pizza and it seemed reasonable. Pulled out the form, wrote the check, sent it back with Emma The next day. Two weeks later, Emma comes home with another catalog, different company, same overpriced garbage. Mrs. Allen's apparently told the kids that the last fundraiser didn't meet expectations and they needed to do another one. Then another catalog the week after that and another one. By October, we'd gotten six different fundraising catalogs, six. Emma kept coming home stressed because Mrs. Allen's would Announce in class how much money each family had contributed so far. She'd literally read out names and amounts during morning announcements. The Johnson family has raised $87 for our school. The Martinez family has contributed $115, like it was some kind of competition. Emma started begging me to order more stuff because she was embarrassed that we'd only bought one thing. Other kids were bragging about how their parents bought three or four items from each catalog. I finally snapped when the seventh catalog came home.

voice_to_text: She hired a hitman to take out her son in law over custody. Right. This happened in 2014, and no one was arrested until 2022. The story is pretty twisted. This is Donna Adelson, the grandmother, but we'll get back to her in a minute. This is her daughter, Wendy Adelson. And this was Wendy's husband, Dan Markel.
